children.heading: Current Situation and Problem Statement [Informative]
children.text: Transportation system managers use SCP in a variety of ways to improve their transportation system operations. The primary uses of SCP data support the following:
To provide for vehicles in need of preferential treatment at signalized intersections;
To improve the on-time performance of public transportation without degrading the overall performance of the traffic network; and
To provide more efficient use of the street network by improving the throughput of travelers and goods.

Signal priority is a process or control strategy to facilitate the movement of fleet vehicles through signalized intersections. SCP is a means of executing the signal priority control strategy. Without SCP, traffic signal controllers at signalized intersections are programmed to treat each vehicle equally, without regard to the type or need of the vehicles at the intersection. With SCP, signal priority can be provided to certain classes of vehicles, if needed.

Signal priority is defined as the preferential treatment of one vehicle class (such as a transit vehicle, emergency service vehicle, or a commercial fleet vehicle) over other vehicle classes at a signalized intersection without causing the traffic signal controllers to drop from coordinated operations. Signal priority may be accomplished by a number of methods including increasing or decreasing the green times on specific phases, changing the phase sequence, omitting a phase, or the inclusion of special phases, without interrupting the general timing relationship between specific green indications at adjacent intersections. The most common vehicle class for which signal priority is given is transit vehicles.

The key to an effective SCP is to facilitate desired fleet vehicle movement at a signalized intersection while minimizing its negative impacts on other vehicles and the traffic network. An effective SCP has little negative impact (and in fact, may have a positive impact) on general traffic. SCP is a cost-effective method to enhance regional mobility through fleet vehicles that transport more people and goods in comparison to single-occupant or smaller vehicles.

SCP is also an inexpensive way to make transit more attractive to travelers. Using SCP can improve schedule adherence, improve transit vehicle efficiency, make transit service more reliable and improve travel times, with minimal negative impacts to normal traffic operations.

The impact of SCP on other vehicles and on the traffic network is what differentiates signal priority from signal pre-emption. Signal priority is a ?request for service? that modifies the signal operation in an orderly fashion to provide preferential treatment to vehicles requesting signal priority. Signal pre-emption is a ?demand for service? that interrupts the signal operation to immediately service the demand. Signal pre-emption often temporarily disrupts any coordination the signal may have with other traffic signals adjacent to it. Signal pre-emption is usually used with an approaching train at a signal-rail intersection or with emergency vehicles, such as a fire engine responding to an incident.

children.heading: Reference Physical Architecture [Informative]
children.text: An SCP can be configured in several ways and generally requires integration of elements from two or more organizations. For example, a fleet organization, such as a transit agency, needs to send its request for preferential treatment to the traffic agency that owns and operates the traffic signal controllers. The specific elements between which communications take place vary depending on how the SCP system is implemented. The communications may be between the fleet management center and the traffic management center, between the fleet vehicle or the traffic signal controller, between a fleet roadside device and the traffic signal controller, or any other combination of the entities mentioned.

attributesChanged.text: An SCP can be configured in several ways and generally requires integration of elements from two or more organizations. For example, a fleet organization, such as a transit agency, needs to send its request for preferential treatment to the traffic agency that owns and operates the traffic signal controllers. The specific elements between which the communications take place vary depending on how the SCP system is implemented. The communications may be between the fleet management center and the traffic management center, between the fleet vehicle or the traffic signal controller, between a fleet roadside device and the traffic signal controller, or any other combination of the entities mentioned.

children.text: The reference architecture is presented according to the rules defined within the Architecture for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT) and defines the overall context of an SCP system, including the:

attributesChanged.text: The reference physical architecture defines the overall context of an SCP system, including the:

children.text: Functional objects that support SCP;

attributesChanged.text: Components of an SCP;
Components of an SCP;

children.text: Typical physical objects associated with SCP deployments; and

attributesChanged.text: Typical physical architectures of an SCP; and

children.text: Specific interfaces addressed by this document.

attributesChanged.text: Specific interfaces addressed by NTCIP 1211 v02.

children.heading: Functional Objects that Support SCP
children.text: All SCP deployments include a Priority Request Generator (PRG), a Priority Request Server (PRS), the Coordinator (CO), and an NTCIP Manager. Deployments may also include PRG proxies. Each of these functions can be contained in a variety of physical objects based on the needs of the particular deployment.

attributesChanged.heading: Components of an SCP
attributesChanged.text: Fundamentally, an SCP consists of three components: a Priority Request Generator (PRG), a Priority Request Server (PRS), and the Coordinator (CO). There are also three secondary components that may make up an SCP system: the Fleet Management Center, the Fleet Vehicle, and the Traffic Management Center.

children.text: The following paragraphs describe the primary functions of these functional objects.

attributesChanged.text: The following paragraphs describe the primary functions of these components.

children.heading: Priority Request Generator (PRG)
children.text: The PRG is a functional object that can be implemented within various physical objects. The PRG may be implemented by a Fleet Vehjicle, a Fleet Management Center, a Traffic Management Center, ITS Roadway Equipment, or elsewhere.

attributesChanged.text: The PRG is a logical entity that can be physically located in various locations. The PRG may be located at a Fleet Management Center, on a Fleet Vehicle, at a Traffic Management Center, within a roadside cabinet, or within the traffic signal controller.

children.text: The primary functions of the PRG are as follows:

To produce an estimate of the time of service desired for a fleet vehicle approaching the signalized intersection. This estimate is intended to represent the vehicle?s arrival time at the intersection and can range from zero (0) (representing a request for immediate service) to some time in the future.

To produce an estimate of the time of departure for a vehicle from the intersection's stopping point. This estimate is intended to represent the vehicle?s departure time from the intersection and can range from zero (0) (representing a vehicle at the intersection) to some time in the future.
To send a request for signal priority, which consists of the time of service desired, the time of estimated departure, and the priority strategy desired to the PRS.
To send and receive the status of a priority request from the PRS.
Standards and specifications relating to the design and functions of the PRG are outside the scope of this document.

attributesChanged.text: Standards and specifications relating to the design and functions of the PRG are outside the scope of NTCIP 1211 v02.

children.text: The SCP WG considered the specification of strategy in developing this document and concluded that the PRG may not know the specific strategy or even the phase that would serve the desired movement, but should know the entering approach, and possibly the exit approach, directions that specify the desired movement of the requesting vehicle at the intersection. The SCP WG is considering proposals for addressing this need in future versions of this document while maintaining backward compatibility with prior versions.

attributesChanged.text: Note: The SCP WG considered the specification of strategy in developing NTCIP 1211 V02 and concluded that the PRG may not know the specific strategy or even the phase that would serve the desired movement, but should know the entering approach, and possibly the exit approach, directions that specify the desired movement of the requesting vehicle at the intersection. The SCP WG is considering proposals for addressing this need in NTCIP 1211 v03 while maintaining backward compatibility with NTCIP 1211 v01.

The SCP WG considered the specification of strategy in developing NTCIP 1211 V02 and concluded that the PRG may not know the specific strategy or even the phase that would serve the desired movement, but should know the entering approach, and possibly the exit approach, directions that specify the desired movement of the requesting vehicle at the intersection. The SCP WG is considering proposals for addressing this need in NTCIP 1211 v03 while maintaining backward compatibility with NTCIP 1211 v01.

children.text: Multiple Fleet Vehicles from different Fleet operations can all produce requests for signal priority.

children.heading: Priority Request Server (PRS)
children.text: The PRS is a functional object that typically is implemented within a device contained in the traffic signal cabinet, either as a separate component or incorporated internally in the traffic signal controller logic. A PRS can also be located in a Traffic Management Center.

attributesChanged.text: In most implementations, the PRS is a logical entity that is located in the traffic signal cabinet and can be implemented as either a separate component installed in the traffic signal cabinet or incorporated internally in the traffic signal controller logic. A PRS can also be located in a Traffic Management Center.

children.text: The primary functions of the PRS are as follows:
To receive priority requests from different PRGs.
To send the status of the priority requests received back to the originating PRG.
To sort the different priority requests received based on the requests? vehicle class level and time of service desired.

attributesChanged.text: To prioritize the different priority requests received based on the requests? vehicle class level and time of service desired.

children.text: To exchange a service request with the CO that has the time of service desired, the time of estimated departure and the priority strategy desired for each priority request.
To exchange the status of the service requests with the CO.
Optionally, to produce a log of all the priority requests received; and the service requests exchanged with the CO.
Optionally, to send the contents of the log to the Traffic Management Center.

children.heading: Coordinator (CO)
children.text: The CO is a functional object that is an integral part of a traffic signal controller. The CO has the primary responsibility for processing the service requests received from the PRS. Each service request consists of the requested time of service, the estimated time of departure, and the priority strategy requested for each priority request received. Also, requests for priority service can be sent to a CO, but a CO cannot be commanded to service a priority request by the SCP system.

attributesChanged.text: The CO is a logical entity that is an integral part of a traffic signal controller. The CO has the primary responsibility for processing the service requests received from the PRS. Each service request consists of the requested time of service, the estimated time of departure, and the priority strategy requested for each priority request received. Also, requests for priority service can be sent to a CO, but a CO cannot be commanded to service a priority request by the SCP system.

children.text: The primary functions of the CO are as follows:
To receive a service request from a PRS.
To send the status of a service request received back to the PRS.
To implement the priority strategy requested in the service request received from the PRS.
Optionally, to produce a log of all the service requests received from the PRS and the priority strategies implemented.
Optionally, to send the contents of the log to the traffic management center upon request.

children.heading: NTCIP Manager
children.text: The NTCIP Manager is a functional object that is responsible for allowing the end user (e.g., field technician, traffic engineer) to configure and manage the SCP system. The primary NTCIP Manager is typically located within a TMC but there may be other instances (e.g., in a field technician’s laptop).
The primary functions of the NTCIP Manager are to allow an end user to perform the following:
Configure the PRS, including both PRS-specific functionality and base functionality (e.g., logging features).
Configure the CO, including both CO-specific functionality and base functionality.

attributesChanged.text: a)     Configure the CO, including both CO-specific functionality and base functionality.

children.text: Monitor the PRS.
Monitor the CO.

children.heading: PRG Proxy
children.text: The PRG Proxy is an optional functional element that is used when the PRG application entity does not communicate directly within the PRS application entity. This is typically due to the PRG not communicating according to the design contained within this document. A PRG Proxy is not needed if intermediate devices act only as communication routers.

For example, the design specified by this document assumes that the PRG communicates directly to the desired PRS, but in some deployments the PRG sends a request to a center that manages multiple PRS deployments (e.g., at different traffic signals). Such a design requires additional information (e.g., to identify the target PRS), which is included in the scope of this document. A PRG Proxy is able to convert messages sent between PRGs and PRSs into their appropriate formats. In some deployment scenarios, there might be multiple PRG proxies in a series.
The primary functions of the PRG Proxy are as follows:
Convert and forward PRG messages to the target PRS.
Convert and forward PRS messages to the target PRG.

children.heading: Management Station
children.text: A management station is defined as a computing platform that manages NTCIP field components, such as a PRS or a CO. A management station may be a traffic management center or a maintenance laptop that a field technician may use on a trip to visit the component.

children.heading: Physical Objects Typically Associated with SCP
children.text: SCP deployments typically include the following physical objects: Traffic Signal Controller, Traffic Management Center, Fleet Vehicle, Fleet Vehicle Driver, and a maintenance technician’s Laptop. SCP deployments can also include Priority Request Server Equipment, Fleet Management Center, and Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment (CV RSE). The following paragraphs describe the primary functions of the physical objects.

children.heading: Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment
children.text: The CV RSE represents equipment that send messages to, and receive messages from, nearby vehicles and nomadic devices (e.g., smartphones) using a trust network that is based on service permissions rather than uniquely identifying specific users. For example, while traditional cybersecurity trust networks are established by securely authenticating the identity of each user and determining their rights based on a previously defined configuration. This is analogous to a officer checking an individual’s identification card and determining if that individual is listed on a sheet to receive priority. The CV RSE trust network is established by users securely presenting certificates that they have the rights being, potentially without directly revealing the name of the individual. This is analogous to providing a permit to the officer that allows the driver to obtain priority.
Within the scope of SCP, the CV RSE can be used to securely receive requests for priority and to translate these requests into SCP priority requests according to the rules of this document.

children.heading: Fleet Management Center
children.text: A Fleet Management Center's role and responsibility vary depending on how the SCP system is implemented. For some SCP implementations, the Fleet Management Center includes a PRG functional object that is capable of monitoring the location of fleet vehicles and generating a priority request for transmission to the Traffic Management Center. In other SCP implementations, the Fleet Management Center only hosts a PRG Proxy functional object and reformats requests generated by the driver into the the priority request format needed by the TMC.

attributesChanged.text: A Fleet Management Center?s role and responsibility vary depending on how the SCP system is implemented. For some SCP implementations, the Fleet Management Center?s responsibility includes receiving vehicle location from Fleet Vehicles, then sending that information to a Traffic Management Center. In other SCP implementations, the Fleet Management Center?s responsibility is to receive priority requests from the PRG, then forwarding those priority requests to a Traffic Management Center. There are other SCP implementations where the Fleet Management Center has no functional role in the data exchanges to request and implement signal priority.

children.heading: Fleet Vehicles
children.text: Fleet Vehicles represent the physical objects that are to be given priority by the Traffic Signal Controller. Within the typical architectures depicted in this document, we assume that Fleet Vehicles are operated by Fleet Vehicle Drivers who respond to visual indications provided by the Traffic Signal Controller, however, this document does not preclude the use of automated driving systems using either image detection technologies or electronic communications (e.g., Signal Phase and Timing messages as defined in ISO 19091). Fleet Vehicles that host their own PRG can directly generate their own requests for transmission to either the Fleet Management Center or directly to roadside devices (e.g., CV RSE), depending on how the SCP system is implemented. Alternatively, the Fleet Vehicle can include some technology that allows the Fleet Management Center to monitor the vehicle’s location so that the Fleet Management Center can generate the request as needed.

attributesChanged.text: The Fleet Vehicles have the primary responsibility for sending their vehicle location either to a PRG or the Fleet Management Center, depending on how the SCP system is implemented.

children.heading: Fleet Vehicle Driver
children.text: The Fleet Vehicle Driver is responsible for interpreting traffic signal indications and operating the Fleet Vehicle in a safe manner and according to traffic laws. Although not discussed in this document, a Fleet Vehicle Driver could potentially be partially or fully replaced with an ADS (Automated Driving System).

children.heading: Laptop
children.text: The Laptop represents a device, typically used by a field technician, to control roadside equipment from the field location. Laptops are often used to reconfigure a device and for diagnostic purposes.

children.heading: Priority Request Server Equipment
children.text: Priority Request Server Equipment represents a device, distinct from the Traffic Signal Controller, that includes the PRS functional object. While the PRS can be included internal to the Traffic Signal Controller, it often is hosted within a separate modular unit that supports a standardized interface as defined in this document.

children.heading: Traffic Management Center
children.text: The Traffic Management Center has the primary responsibility for installing, configuring, operating, and maintaining a PRS and a CO. The PRS and CO should be capable of being configured remotely by the Traffic Management Center via the NTCIP manager functional object. For some SCP implementations, the Traffic Management Center also hosts a PRG Proxy, which is responsible for receiving priority requests from Fleet Management Centers and reformatting those priority requests to the PRS as an SCP priority request. Finally, the TMC can also host its own PRG, which could generate its own SCP priority requests according to locally defined policies.

attributesChanged.text: The Traffic Management Center has the primary responsibility for installing, configuring, operating, and maintaining a PRS and a CO. The PRS and CO should be capable of being configured remotely by the Traffic Management Center via a management station. For some SCP implementations, the Traffic Management Center is also responsible for receiving priority requests from Fleet Management Centers and forwarding those priority requests to the PRS.

children.heading: Traffic Signal Controller
children.text: The Traffic Signal Controller has the primary responsibility for timing the traffic signal per its configuration while constantly ensuring safe operations. The Traffic Signal Controller includes the CO to manage how to provide priority within the confines of the controller’s current configuration. It is also responsible for communicating with the PRS and maintaining logs as configured.

children.heading: Information Flows
children.text: This document defines the following information flows as shown in the physical view diagrams caontained in subsection 2.3.4. These information flows are more detailed than what is shown in ARC-IT but less detailed than the messages provided within this standard. They are intended to provide the reader with a high-level view of the interfaces addressed by this document.
PRG <--> PRS

scp priority request: This information flow allows a SCP priority request to be submitted to a PRS. Logically, the source of the information flow is the PRG, but depending on the physical configuration, it may be submitted via a PRG Proxy.
scp priority status: This information flow allows a PRS to provide the status of a prior request to the originating PRG (or PRG Proxy).
PRS <--> CO
scp service request: This information flow allows a PRS to submit the highest priority request to the CO for processing.
scp service status: This information flow allows a PRS to discover the status of a previously submitted request to the CO.
NTCIP Manager <--> PRS

priority request server configuration: This information flow allows an NTCIP manager to configure a PRS. The configuration includes parameters related to the operation of the PRS as well as generic features, such as configuring the logging feature.
priority request server status: This information flow allows an NTCIP manager to discover the current configuration and status of the PRS.
NTCIP Manager <--> CO

coordinator configuration: This information flow allows an NTCIP manager to configure a PRS. The configuration includes parameters related to the operation of the CO as well as generic features, such as configuring the logging feature.
coordinator status: This information flow allows an NTCIP manager to discover the current configuration and status of the CO.

children.heading: Typical View Diagrams for SCP
children.text: There are many different possible physical configurations associated with an SCP system. This subsection illustrates the interfaces addressed by this document by depicting several possible physical configurations of an SCP deployment using physical view diagrams. The primary purpose of showing a range of diagrams is to demonstrate how the eight information flows addressed by this document support a wide variety of configurations. However, not all flows are used in all configurations. The differences between the physical view diagrams are:

attributesChanged.heading: Typical Physical Architectures of an SCP
attributesChanged.text: There are many different possible physical configurations associated with an SCP system. This section illustrates only some of the possible physical configurations (or architectures) of an SCP. The differences between the physical architectures are:

There are many different possible physical configurations associated with an SCP system. This subsection illustrates the interfaces addressed by this document by depicting several possible physical configurations of an SCP deployment using physical view diagrams. The differences between the physical architectures are:

children.text: the physical object that hosts the PRG;

attributesChanged.text: the physical location of the PRG;

children.text: the physical object that hosts the PRS; and

attributesChanged.text: if the PRS is a physical or a logical entity, and the location of the PRS; and

children.text: the intermediary physical objects that exist between the PRG and the PRS, if any.

attributesChanged.text: the intermediary entities between the PRG and the PRS, if any.
the intermediary entities between the PRG and the PRS, if any.

children.text: These diagrams only depict the functional objects and information flows relevant to managing SCP for a traffic signal. Other functions (e.g., traffic signal control functions) are omitted for simplicity. Inclusion of these diagrams does not imply that these are preferred configurations; many other configurations are possible.

attributesChanged.text: Note: The physical architecture illustrations that follow assume that the PRS is implemented as a physical entity. It is possible that a traffic signal controller design integrates all the functions of a PRS as a logical entity within the controller, or that a traffic management center integrates all the functions of a PRS as a logical entity within the traffic management software. It is also possible that the traffic signal controller design integrates all the functions of a PRG as a logical entity within the controller.

children.heading: Example Architecture 1
children.text: The first example physical view diagram (Figure 1) represents a case in which the PRG resides in the Fleet Vehicle but there is no direct communications path between the Fleet Vehicle and the Traffic Signal Controller.

attributesChanged.text: The first example physical architecture (Figure 1) represents a case in which the PRG resides in the Fleet Vehicle but there is no direct communications path between the Fleet Vehicle and the Traffic Signal Controller.

children.text: Because there is no direct communications path between the Fleet Vehicle and the Traffic Signal Controller, the Fleet Vehicle sends a "driver to fleet request" for signal priority to the Fleet Management Center. While this information flow contains the necessary information to request priority, does not connect directly to the PRS and as such is not envisioned to be addressed by this standard.

attributesChanged.text: In this architecture, the PRG sends a "priority request" but because there is no direct communications path between the Fleet Vehicle and the Traffic Signal Controller, the priority request is routed through the Fleet Management Center (see Interface #6 in Figure 1) and the Traffic Management Center (#5). This example logically treats the Fleet Vehicle, the Fleet Management Center, and the Traffic Management Center as the PRG because the Fleet Management Center and the Traffic Management Center only act as intermediaries to forward the priority request and the status of the priority request between the PRG on the Fleet Vehicle and the PRS.

children.text: The Fleet Management Center acts as a PRG Proxy and forwards the request to the Traffic Management Center as a “traffic control priority request”. Once again, the request contains the necessary details to make a request, but the interface does not connect directly to the PRS and as such is not envisioned to be addressed by this standard.

attributesChanged.text: Thus, for this example, the PRG consists of the Fleet Vehicle, the Fleet Management Center, and the Traffic Management Center. The (?logical?) PRG sends the priority request to the PRS (#1). The PRS can physically reside, either partially or in total, in either the Traffic Management Center or on the roadside, but is a logical entity that receives multiple "priority requests" and sends the status of each ?priority request? back to the (?logical?) PRG. Within the (?logical?) PRG, the Traffic Management Center then forwards the status of the priority request back to Fleet Management Center (#5), which in turn may forward the status of the priority request back to the Fleet Vehicle (#6).

children.text: The Traffic Management Center also acts as a PRG Proxy and forwards the request to the Priority Request Server within the Priority Request Server Equipment using the “scp priority request” information flow. This flow includes support for initial requests, updates, cancellations, etc. and is directly addressed by this document.

attributesChanged.text: NTCIP 1211 v02 does not cover the communications interfaces between the Fleet Vehicle and Fleet Management Center (#6), or between the Fleet Management Center and Traffic Management Center (#5) because NTCIP 1211 v02 is a center-to-field communications standard. Other standards, such as TCIP, a transit communications standard, or TMDD, a center-to-center standard, should be considered for the Fleet Vehicle to Fleet Management Center communications interface and for the Fleet Management Center to Traffic Management Center communications interface, respectively. However, the information exchanges between these entities should include the information necessary for the Fleet Vehicle, Fleet Management Center and the Traffic Management Center to forward and receive the priority request and the status of a priority request.

children.text:
The Priority Request Server can manage multiple requests from potentially different sources and sends the highest priority request to the SCP Coordinator within the Traffic Signal Controller using the “scp service request” flow. According to its internal logic (not addressed by this standard), the Traffic Signal Controller grants priority at the appropriate time so that it can be perceived by the driver (e.g., by controlling the display on its signal heads). 

The Priority Request Server is responsible for monitoring the status of its request by using the “scp service status” flow. Both flows between the PRS and CO are addressed by this document.

attributesChanged.text: Besides the (?logical?) PRG and the PRS interface for this physical architecture, NTCIP 1211 v02 addresses the communications interfaces between Traffic Management Center and the PRS (#1); between the Traffic Management Center and the CO (#2); and between the PRS and the CO (#4).

The Priority Request Server can manage multiple requests from potentially different sources and sends the highest priority request to the SCP Coordinator within the Traffic Signal Controller using the “scp service request” flow. According to its internal logic (not addressed by this standard), the Traffic Signal Controller grants priority at the appropriate time so that it can be perceived by the driver (e.g., by controlling the display on its signal heads).

children.text: The TMC can request the status of current requests by using the “scp priority status” flow, which is also addressed by this document. The TMC can then provide this information to the Fleet Management Center via the “traffic control priority status” flow, which can then be sent to the Fleet Vehicle using the “fleet to driver update” flow; neither of which are covered by this document.

attributesChanged.text: The PRS processes the priority requests received from the PRG and sends "service requests" to the CO (#4), the logical entity in the Traffic Signal Controller that processes the service request. The CO then responds to the PRS with the status of the service request.

children.text: In addition to handling priority requests as described above, this document also addresses flows for configuring and monitoring both the Priority Request Server and the SCP Coordinator from an NTCIP Manager, which typically resides in either a TMC or on a field technician’s laptop computer. These flows include “priority request server configuration”, “priority request server status”, “coordinator configuration”, and “coordinator status”.
In this configuration the TMC serves as a proxy for the PRG in its interface with the PRS.

attributesChanged.text: Both the PRS and the CO also may log events, which are then retrieved by the Traffic Management Center (#1 and #2, respectively). The Traffic Management Center is also responsible for configuring the PRS and the CO.
Figure 1 Physical Architecture Example 1

children.heading: Example Architecture 2
children.text: Example 2 is a slight simplification of Example 1 in that the PRG is physically located in the Fleet Management Center rather than in the Fleet Vehicle. In this case, the Fleet Management Center monitors the status of its Fleet Vehicle (e.g., by monitoring the “vehicle schedule performance”) and decides when to request priority. The data that the Fleet Management Center obtains from the Fleet Vehicle is not addressed in this document. The rest of the diagram is identical to that described in Example 1.

attributesChanged.text: Physical architecture example 2 is a slight variation of physical architecture example 1 in that the PRG is physically located in the Fleet Management Center. As shown in Figure 2, the PRG is located in the Fleet Management Center, but there is no direct communication between the Fleet Management Center and the Traffic Signal Controller.

Physical architecture example 2 is a slight simplification of Example 1 in that the PRG is physically located in the Fleet Management Center rather than in the Fleet Vehicle. In this case, the Fleet Management Center monitors the status of its Fleet Vehicle (e.g., by monitoring the “vehicle schedule performance”) and decides when to request priority. The data that the Fleet Management Center obtains from the Fleet Vehicle is not addressed in this document. The rest of the diagram is identical to that described in Example 1.

children.text: Similar to Example 1, the TMC serves as a proxy for the PRG in its interface with the PRS.

attributesChanged.text: Besides the (?logical?) PRG and the PRS interface for this physical architecture, NTCIP 1211 v02 addresses the communications interfaces between Traffic Management Center and the PRS (#1); between the Traffic Management Center and the CO (#2); and between the PRS and the CO (#4). The processes and data exchanges between these three interfaces are the same as those in physical architecture example #1.
Figure 2 Physical Architecture Example 2

children.heading: Example Architecture 3
children.text: Physical architecture Example 3 is a further simplification in that the PRG is physically located in the Traffic Management Center rather than the Fleet Management Center or Fleet Vehicle. In this case, the Traffic Management Center determines the need for priority in a manner not defined in this document and submits its request directly to the PRS in the Priority Request Server Equipment. The rest of the diagram is identical to that described in Example 1.

attributesChanged.text: Physical architecture example 3 is another variation of the first two physical architectures in that the PRG resides either as a logical or physical entity in the Traffic Management Center (see Figure 3). The PRG initiates a priority request and sends the priority request to the PRS, which can reside in part or in whole in the Traffic Management Center or on the roadside (see Interface #3 in Figure 3). The PRS may receive multiple "priority requests" and returns the status of each ?priority request? back to the PRG.

children.text: In this example, the TMC serves the PRG rather than a proxy.

attributesChanged.text: The PRS also processes the priority requests to send "service requests" to the CO, the logical entity in the Traffic Signal Controller that processes the service request (#4). The CO then responds to the PRS with the status of the service request. Both the PRS and the CO may log events, which are retrieved by the Traffic Management Center (#1 and #2, respectively). The Traffic Management Center is also responsible for configuring the PRS and the CO.
Figure 3 Physical Architecture Example 3

children.heading: Example Architecture 4
children.text: The fourth example of a typical SCP physical architecture is one where the Fleet Vehicle directly communicates with the PRS, which is located within the field-based Priority Request Server Equipment. In this configuration, the “scp priority request” flow is still generated by the PRG (as in example 3), but it is now located within the Fleet Vehicle. Likewise, the “scp priority status” flow responds to the PRG in the Fleet Vehicle. As stated before, these flows are addressed by this standard. (i.e., This architecture assumes that the Fleet Vehicle - PRS interface will be a wireless implementation of an NTCIP protocol.) The rest of the diagram is identical to that described in the prior examples.

attributesChanged.text: The fourth example of a typical SCP physical architecture is one in which there is a direct communications link between the Fleet Vehicle and the traffic signal cabinet (see Figure 4). As in physical architecture example 1, the PRG resides within a Fleet Vehicle and sends a priority request. However, in this example physical architecture, the PRG sends the priority request directly to a PRS, which is a logical or physical entity located in the traffic signal cabinet (see Interface #3 in Figure 4). The PRS receives the priority requests, processes them, and resolves them to a service request that is sent to the CO for processing (#4). The CO then responds back to the PRS with the status of the service request. The PRS may also return the status of each priority request back to the PRG.

children.text: In this diagram, the Fleet Vehicle might communicate to the PRS through Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment (CV RSE), however in this example, the CV RSE only acts as a router and per ARC-IT conventions routers are not shown on physical view diagrams.

attributesChanged.text: For this physical architecture, NTCIP 1211 v02 covers the communications interfaces between Traffic Management Center and the PRS (#1); between the Traffic Management Center and the CO(#2); between the PRG and the PRS (#3); and between the PRS and the CO (#4).
Figure 4 Physical Architecture Example 4

children.heading: Example Architecture 5
children.text: Physical architecture example 5 is similar to example 4 but the Fleet Vehicle uses a non-NTCIP protocol (e.g., ISO 19091 and SAE J2945/B) to communicate to the roadside. In this case, the Fleet Vehicle communicates its non-NTCIP request to a CV RSE that translates the request into the “scp priority request” flow” addressed in this document (i.e., the CV RSE contains a PRG Proxy). This flow is provided to the PRS as discussed in the other examples. Likewise, the CV RSE receives the “scp priority status” from the PRS and translates it into the non-NTCIP format for transmission to the PRG in the Fleet Vehicle. The rest of the diagram is identical to that described in Example 1.

attributesChanged.heading: Physical Architecture Example 5
attributesChanged.text: Physical architecture example 5 is one where the PRG is located in a field cabinet, and there is a direct communications link between the PRG and the traffic signal cabinet (see Figure 5). There is also a direct communications path between the PRG and either the Fleet Vehicle or the Fleet Management Center. The PRG sends a priority request directly to a PRS, which is a logical or physical entity located in the traffic signal cabinet (See Interface #3 in Figure 5). The PRS receives the priority service requests, processes them, and resolves them to one or more priority service requests that are sent to the CO for processing (#4). The CO then responds back to the PRS with the status of the service request. The PRS may also send the status of each priority request back to the PRG. Both the PRS and the CO may log events, which are retrieved by the Traffic Management Center (#1 and #2, respectively). The Traffic Management Center is also responsible for configuring the PRS and the CO.

NTCIP 1211 v02 does not cover the communications interface between the Fleet Management Center and the PRG (#5) or between the Fleet Vehicle and the PRG (#6). Other standards, such as TCIP, a transit communications standard, should be considered for these communications interfaces. However, the information exchanges between these entities should include the information necessary for the PRG to send a priority request.

children.heading: Example Architecture 6
children.text: A final example provided within this document combines the PRG, PRS, and CO into one physical object called “ITS Roadside Equipment” (IRE). The IRE might consist of multiple devices, but this example assumes that the interfaces among any such devices are implementation specific and do necessarily conform to any standard.

attributesChanged.text: A sixth example of a typical SCP physical architecture is one in which there is a direct communications link between the Fleet Vehicle and the traffic signal cabinet and the functions of the PRG, PRS, and CO are all performed within the traffic signal cabinet, i.e., the logical entities PRG, PRS, and CO are all physically located within the traffic signal cabinet (see Figure 6).

children.text: This example physical view diagram is probably the most common implementation of an SCP system, at the time that this document was written. For example, a common implementation uses an infrared transmitter or similar device on a fleet vehicle to transmit an encoded pulse that can be used to identify the vehicle as a fleet vehicle with special permissions. A receiver located near the traffic signal can be used to detect the encoded pulse and recognize the presence of the vehicle. The receiver then sends a signal to the traffic signal controller through a port, generally a contact closure, to indicate the request for a preferential treatment. Depending on the implementation, there may be multiple ports (or contact closures) between the receiver and the traffic signal controller, one port for each vehicle class or direction for preferential treatment.

attributesChanged.text: This example physical architecture is probably the most common implementation of an SCP system, where an infrared transmitter on a fleet vehicle sends an encoded pulse to a receiver located near the traffic signal controller (see Interface #4 in Figure 6). The receiver then sends a signal to the traffic signal controller through a port, generally a contact closure, to indicate the request for a preferential treatment (#3). Depending on the implementation of the SCP system, there may be multiple ports (or contact closures) between the receiver and the traffic signal controller, one port for each vehicle class or direction for preferential treatment.

children.text: This example only uses four of the information flows addressed in this standard (i.e., those used between the NTCIP Manager and either the PRS or the CO). The other four flows are internal to the IRE and not addressed by this document.

attributesChanged.text: Within the traffic signal cabinet, the PRG reads the signal from the transmitter through the appropriate port and selects a priority strategy. The PRS prioritizes the priority requests, if there is more than one, and the CO then implements the priority strategy selected. Both the PRS and the CO may log events, which are retrieved by the Traffic Management Center (#1 and #2, respectively). The Traffic Management Center is also responsible for configuring the PRS and the CO.
Figure 6 Physical Architecture Example 6

children.heading: Architectural Needs
children.text: All the architectural needs are defined within the user needs of ISO 26048-1. Commonly used architectural needs within the scope of SCP are listed in the PRL with references to the relevant ISO 26048-1 clauses.

attributesChanged.text: This section defines the communications environment within which an SCP system is expected to operate.

children.heading: ISO 26048-1 Needs Included
children.text: All the architectural needs are defined within the user needs of ISO 26048-1. Commonly used architectural needs within the scope of a ESS are listed in the PRL with references to the relevant ISO 26048-1 clauses and include the following:

children.heading: Authenticate users
children.text: allows users to ensure that all communications with the device are with authenticated users.

children.heading: Control access to data
children.text: allows administrators to configure the detailed access privileges that are granted to each authenticated user.

children.heading: Monitor failed access to the field device
children.text: allows administrators to discover when unauthorized attempts are made to access the device.

children.heading: Manage the field device
children.text: allows a user to remotely reset the controller and configure and monitor basic information about the field device, such as its:
Identity,
Location,
Power source,
Default language,
Capabilities (e.g., which objects are supported, maximum message size),
Status, and
Configuration identifier.

children.heading: Monitor ambient air temperature
children.text: The body of this document provides a more robust way to monitor ambient air temperature (2.5.2.1.3) that predates the design contained in ISO 26048-1.

children.heading: Monitor ambient relative humidity
children.text: The body of this document provides a more robust way to monitor ambient relative humidity (2.5.2.1.4) that predates the design contained in ISO 26048-1.

children.heading: Monitor ambient light
children.text: allows the device to measure ambient light levels (e.g., from the sun).

children.heading: Monitor field device enclosure
children.text: allows a user to monitor the device environment and enclosure(s), including:

children.heading: Monitor field device enclosure air temperature
Manage enclosure climate control components
children.text: allows a user to monitor and control climate control components, including:

children.heading: Monitor field device power
children.text: allows a user to monitor and control power equipment, including:

children.heading: Manage auxiliary ports
children.text: allows a user to monitor and control support equipment, including:

children.heading: Manage field device auxiliary bi-directional ports
Receive notification of triggers firing
children.text: allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically receive an SNMP notification when the trigger condition occurs.

children.heading: Manage device-specific notifications
children.text: allows the user to configure all supported notifications to use notification channels, which prevent notifications from flooding the communications channel.

children.heading: Log system events
children.text: allows the device to record information about internal events that can be of interest during forensic analysis, e.g., for debugging purposes.

children.heading: Log user-defined data snapshots
children.text: allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically log information when the trigger condition occurs.

children.heading: Record a series of data snapshots
children.text: allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically log a series of snapshots based on the trigger condition occurring. For example, when the cabinet door opens, record the cabinet temperature once a second for 60 seconds.

children.heading: Configure a complex device
children.text: allows a user to buffer changes to a large number of inter-related configuration parameters so that the proposed changes can be validated as a whole prior to ensure a safe configuration prior to implementation. This feature is prohibited in implementations of NTCIP 1209v03 to promote better interoperability without having devices enter an unexpected state.

children.heading: ISO 26048-1 Needs not Envisioned for SCP
Issue trigger-based commands
children.text: allows a user to define trigger conditions (e.g., an object value exceeding a defined value) and to automatically send another device an SNMP set request when the trigger condition occurs. For example, when ice is detected by a pavement sensor, command an attached gate to close (however, this example is discouraged as a gate closure should include verification mechanisms not offered by this feature to ensure safe operations).

children.heading: Efficient exchange of data
children.text: allows a management station to define dynamic objects that can be used for frequent requests to reduce communications overhead. For example, rather than monitoring 15 discreet status objects, the 15 objects can be placed into a dynamic object and retrieved as a single entity. This can be useful when a management station frequently exchanges a large number of integer values with the device.

children.heading: Features
children.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various user needs (features) that may be offered by an SCP system. It is organized by the four interfaces covered by this document:

attributesChanged.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various user needs (features) that may be offered by an SCP system. It is organized by the four interfaces covered by NTCIP 1211 v02:

children.text: Interface—NTCIP Manager to PRS

attributesChanged.text: Interface?Management Station to PRS
Interface—Management Station to PRS

children.text: Interface—NTCIP Manager to CO

attributesChanged.text: Interface?Management Station to CO
Interface—Management Station to CO

children.text: Interface—PRG to PRS

attributesChanged.text: Interface?PRG to PRS

children.text: Interface—PRS to CO

attributesChanged.text: Interface?PRS to CO

children.heading: Interface—Management Station to PRS
children.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various features that may be offered between a management station and a PRS in an SCP system. These features include:
Manage the PRS
Determine Priority Request Criteria
Monitor the PRS
Retrieve Log Data from the PRS

children.heading: Manage the PRS
children.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various features a management station needs to configure within the PRS.

attributesChanged.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various features a management station needs to configure the PRS.

children.heading: Reserved
children.text: NOTE—This header was previously used by the " Determine PRS Identity" user need, which has been replaced by the “Controller feature” contained in ISO 26048-1, 8.6. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

attributesChanged.heading: Determine PRS Identity
attributesChanged.text: A management station may need to determine basic information about the PRS, such as the type, technology, manufacturer, model, and version number of the PRS. It includes the ability to access information about both hardware and software elements of the PRS.

NOTE — This header was previously used by the " Determine PRS Identity" user need, which has been replaced by the “Controller feature” contained in ISO 26048-1, 8.6. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

children.heading: Reserved
children.text: NOTE—This header was previously used by the " Determine PRS Configuration" user need, which has been replaced by the “Controller feature” contained in ISO 26048-1, 8.6. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

attributesChanged.heading: Determine PRS Configuration
attributesChanged.text: A management station may need to determine the version of the configuration data of the PRS. This feature allows an operator to determine if the configuration of a PRS has changed.

children.heading: Configure Reservice Period
children.text: A management station needs to define the reservice period, which is the minimum amount of time between completing the service of one priority request and the time a subsequent priority request is serviced. This feature allows an operator to prevent the PRS from constantly servicing priority requests, therefore disrupting traffic flow. This feature also helps maintain headways to prevent bunching of transit vehicles.

attributesChanged.text: A management station needs to define the reservice period between when servicing one priority request is completed and when a subsequent priority request is serviced. This feature allows an operator to prevent the PRS from constantly servicing priority requests, therefore disrupting traffic flow. This feature also helps maintain headways to prevent bunching of transit vehicles.

children.heading: Configure Time To Live Period
children.text: A management station needs to define the maximum period of time that a PRS considers a priority request. This feature allows an operator to manage the performance of the traffic network by not servicing priority requests that are sent by a PRG too early.

children.heading: PRS Clock Synchronization
children.text: A management station needs to synchronize the clock on the PRS. This feature allows an operator to check that the PRS is synchronized with the traffic signal controller and the event log timestamps are synchronized with the management station.

children.heading: Determine Priority Request Criteria
children.text: A management station needs to determine the criteria that a PRS uses to manage priority requests. The feature allows an operator to determine how a PRS is currently programmed to handle priority requests.

children.heading: Monitor the PRS
children.text: A management station needs to monitor the status and time of service of the service requests from the PRS. This feature allows an operator to determine what priority strategy a CO is currently using to service a priority request.

children.heading: Reserved
children.text: NOTE—This header was previously used by the "Retrieve Log Data from the PRS" user need, which has been replaced by the “Log user-defined snapshots” user need contained in ISO 26048-1, 6.5. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

attributesChanged.heading: Retrieve Log Data from the PRS
attributesChanged.text: A management station may need to retrieve a PRS?s event logs. Examples of events that may need to be logged include the time when a priority request was received, information contained in the priority request, if a service request to a CO was sent, and what parameters were selected for the service request by the PRS. This feature may be used for performance monitoring purposes, such as to determine how often a priority request is received from a PRG, how often a priority request is granted, and how often a priority strategy is selected.

NOTE—This header was previously used by the " Retrieve Log Data from the PRS" user need, which has been replaced by the “Log user-defined snapshots” user need contained in ISO 26048-1, 6.5. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

children.heading: Interface—Management Station to CO
children.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various features that may be offered between a management station and a CO in an SCP system. These features include:
Configure Priority Strategies
Determine Priority Strategies
Monitor the CO
Retrieve Log Data from the CO

children.heading: Configure Priority Strategies
children.text: A management station needs to define and edit the priority strategies that a CO may implement to provide signal priority. Each priority strategy defines the phases being serviced, the phases to be omitted, the maximum green time that can be reduced, or the maximum green time that can be extended to service the priority. This feature allows an operator to configure the priority strategies so that the traffic signal controller minimizes any negative impacts on the traffic network when servicing a priority request.

children.heading: Determine Priority Strategies
children.text: A management station needs to determine what priority strategies have been programmed in a CO. This feature allows an operator to determine what phases are serviced, what phases are omitted, and how much time a green phase can be extended or reduced for each priority strategy.

discussion.comment:
Retrieve Priority Strategy Settings is redundant with Retrieve Priority Strategy Splits (and I suspect the intent was to make it redundant with Retrieve Priority Strategies but the requirement does not trace to that block object although the design did)...


In short, the Strategy Settings requirement traces to block objects whereas the Strategy and Split requirements trace to individual objects. I am not sure that we really need both.
Unclear why retrieving maximum numbers are optional, these should probably be mandatory.

children.heading: Monitor the CO
children.text: A management station needs to monitor the status of service requests at the CO. This feature allows an operator to determine what priority strategy a CO is currently using to service a priority request.

children.heading: Reserved
children.text: NOTE—This header was previously used by the "Retrieve Log Data from the CO" user need, which has been replaced by the “Log user-defined snapshots” user need contained in ISO 26048-1, 6.5. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

attributesChanged.heading: Retrieve Log Data from the CO
attributesChanged.text: A management station may need to retrieve a CO?s event logs. Examples of events that may need to be logged include the time when a service request was received, information contained in the service request, and which strategy was implemented by the CO. This feature may be used for performance monitoring purposes, such as to determine the effectiveness of the operational strategies and how often a priority request is serviced.

NOTE—This header was previously used by the " Retrieve Log Data from the CO" user need, which has been replaced by the “Log user-defined snapshots” user need contained in ISO 26048-1, 6.5. The heading number has been preserved so that all subsequent user needs have the same heading number as used in previous versions of this document. NTCIP reserves the right to reassign the meaning of this heading in future versions of this document.

children.heading: Interface—PRG to PRS
children.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various features that may be offered between a PRG and a PRS in an SCP system. These features include:
Exchange Priority Requests
Exchange Priority Request Status

children.heading: Exchange Priority Requests
children.text: A PRG needs to send priority requests to a PRS. A priority request consists of the class of the vehicle requesting priority, strategy selected, time of service desired and the estimated time of departure. This feature provides a PRS with the information necessary to determine if a priority request should be granted.

children.heading: Exchange Priority Request Status
children.text: A PRG needs to receive the status of a priority request from a PRS. This feature allows a PRG to verify if a previously sent priority request has been received. The PRG may also use the status to inform the fleet vehicle or fleet management center who requested preferential treatment if its priority request has been granted or not.

children.heading: Interface—PRS to CO
children.text: The following subsections identify and describe the various features that may be offered between a PRS and a CO in an SCP system. These features include:
Exchange Service Requests
Exchange Service Request Status

children.heading: Exchange Service Requests
children.text: If a priority request is granted, a service request needs to be exchanged between the PRS and the CO. Each service request specifies a priority strategy to be implemented, the time of service requested, and the time of estimated departure. This feature provides the priority strategy to the CO for processing and servicing.

children.heading: Exchange Service Request Status
children.text: A PRS and a CO need to exchange the status of a service request. This feature allows the PRS to verify if a previously sent priority request has been received by the CO. The PRS may also use the status to determine if the CO has provided the signal priority.

children.heading: Backward Compatibility Needs
children.text: All prior versions of this document failed to provide adequate security; therefore, this document does not identify any user needs to support backward compatibility.

children.heading: Security
children.text: This document standardizes the objects that can be used by a remote entity to monitor and/or control a device. Allowing remote operations without providing sufficient information security can have a negative effect on the communications network and/or the transportation system. In particular, the misconfiguration of "read-write" and/or "read-create" objects can result in the activation of unauthorized features (e.g., access to unauthorized signal priority) or unauthorized changes to the device configuration; these changes can result in potentially hazardous situations.

attributesChanged.text: NTCIP 1211 v02 does not address any security issues. Any security pertaining to protecting the communications within the SCP system should be implemented either physically by protecting the communications access points, or logically by enabling security features associated with the underlying communications protocols.

children.text: Further, even failing to secure exchanges of "read-only" objects can have harmful effects. Providing unauthorized access to read-only objects can reveal information about the device that can be useful in conducting a cyber-attack against the device itself, other devices, and potentially the central system. Likewise, failing to authenticate the source of the read-only data allows a cyber threat actor to potentially impersonate the device and provide false information to a traffic management center.

The object types defined by this document are intended to be transmitted over SNMPv3. SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3 do not include adequate security. Prior SNMP versions do not provide any control as to who on the network is allowed to access and read/change/create/delete objects, even if the network itself is secure.

children.heading: Security Requirements
children.text: To claim conformance to this standard, an implementation shall not support SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3. An implementation that supports SNMPv3 and prior versions shall:

attributesChanged.text: To provide adequate information security, deployments should:
To claim conformance to this standard, an implementation shall not support SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3. An implementation that supports SNMPv3 and prior versions shall:

children.text: Allow users to disable SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3 and
Allow users to disable SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3 and
Implementations should support the communications stack defined in NTCIP 2301.

children.heading: Security Guidance for Deployments
children.text: To provide adequate information security, deployments should:
Disable any SNMP versions prior to SNMPv3 as soon as possible,
Use the communications stack defined in NTCIP 2301, and
Ensure that implementations are properly configured to only give read and/or, write access to objects based on the legitimate needs of each principal (i.e., user).

children.heading: Relationship to the ITS National Architecture [Informative]
children.text: This document addresses seven information flows included in the Architecture Reference for Cooperative and Intelligent Transportation (ARC-IT). These flows are:

attributesChanged.text: NTCIP 1211 v02 addresses seven National ITS Architecture Flows. These flows are:

children.text: Local signal priority request
Right-of-way request notification
Signal control command
Signal control status
Traffic control priority request
Traffic control priority status
Transit vehicle schedule performance

children.heading: Interfaces
children.text: Each Information Flow is associated with at least one of the following interfaces identified within ARC-IT as:

attributesChanged.text: Each Architecture Flow is associated with one of the following interfaces identified within the National ITS Architecture as:

children.text: Between a Traffic Management Center and ITS Roadway Equipment (e.g., a traffic signal controller)

attributesChanged.text: Between the Traffic Management Center (Traffic Management Subsystem (TMS)) and the Traffic Signal Controller (Roadway Subsystem (RS))

children.text: Between a Traffic Management Center and a Transit Management Center

attributesChanged.text: Between the Traffic Management Center (Traffic Management Subsystem (TMS)) and the Transit Management Center (Transit Management Subsystem (TRMS))
Between the Traffic Management Center and the ITS Roadway Equipment (e.g., a traffic signal controller)

children.text: Between a Transit Vehicle On-Board Equipment (OBE) and a Transit Management Center

attributesChanged.text: Between the Transit Vehicle (Transit Vehicle Subsystem (TRVS)) and the Traffic Signal Controller (Roadway Subsystem (RS))

children.text: Between a specialized Vehicle OBE (e.g., Transit Vehicle OBE) and Connected Vehicle Roadside Equipment

data.heading: Functional Requirements [Normative]
data.text: This section defines the Functional Requirements based on the user needs identified in the Concept of Operations, as defined in Section 2.

attributesChanged.text: Functional Requirements [Normative]
Section 3 defines the Functional Requirements based on the user needs identified in the Concept of Operations (see Section 2). Section 3 includes:

children.text: This section is intended for all readers, including:

attributesChanged.text: Section 3 is intended for all readers, including:

children.text: Transportation operations managers
Transportation operations personnel
Transportation engineers
System integrators
Device manufacturers

For the first three categories of readers, this section is useful in understanding the details that this document requires of an SCP. For these readers, Section 3.3.3 is particularly useful in preparing procurement specifications and in guiding the reader to trace between the detailed text of user needs to the detailed text of requirements.

attributesChanged.text: For the first three categories of readers, Section 3 is useful in understanding the details that NTCIP 1211 v02 requires of an SCP. For these readers, Section 3.3.3 is particularly useful in preparing procurement specifications and assist in mapping the various rows of this table to the more detailed text contained within the other sections.

children.text: For the last two categories of readers, this section is useful to fully understand what is required of equipment to be conformant with this document. The table in Section 3.3.3 may be used to document the capabilities of their implementations.

attributesChanged.text: For the last two categories of readers, this section is useful to fully understand what is required of equipment meeting this interface standard. The table in Section 3.3.3 may be used to document the capabilities of their implementations.

children.heading: Tutorial [Informative]
children.text: This Functional Requirements section defines the formal requirements that are intended to satisfy the user needs identified in Section 2. This is achieved through the development of a PRL that traces each user need to one or more requirements defined in this section. The details of each requirement are then presented following the PRL. The functional requirements are presented in three broad categories as follows:

Architectural Requirements—These requirements define the required behavior of the system in exchanging data across the communications interface, including any restrictions to general architectural requirements, based upon the architectural needs identified in the Concept of Operations.

attributesChanged.text: Architectural Requirements?These requirements define the required behavior of the system in exchanging data across the communications interface, including any restrictions to general architectural requirements, based upon the architectural needs identified in the Concept of Operations.

children.text: Data Exchange Requirements—These requirements define the required behavior of the system in exchanging data across the communications interface based upon the features identified in the Concept of Operations.

attributesChanged.text: Data Exchange Requirements?These requirements define the required behavior of the system in exchanging data across the communications interface based upon the features identified in the Concept of Operations.

children.text: Supplemental Requirements—These requirements define additional requirements of the system that are derived from the architectural and/or data exchange requirements, but are not themselves architectural or data exchange requirements. A given supplemental requirement may relate to multiple architectural and/or data exchange requirements. Supplemental requirements frequently include capabilities of the equipment (e.g., service processing or clearing expired priority requests).

attributesChanged.text: Supplemental Requirements?These requirements define additional requirements of the system that are derived from the architectural and/or data exchange requirements, but are not themselves architectural or data exchange requirements. A given supplemental requirement may relate to multiple architectural and/or data exchange requirements. Supplemental requirements include capabilities of the equipment (e.g., service processing or clearing expired priority requests).

Supplemental Requirements—These requirements define additional requirements of the system that are derived from the architectural and/or data exchange requirements, but are not themselves architectural or data exchange requirements. A given supplemental requirement may relate to multiple architectural and/or data exchange requirements. Supplemental requirements include capabilities of the equipment (e.g., service processing or clearing expired priority requests).

children.text: The PRL in Table 5 maps the user needs defined in Section 2 to the requirements defined in Section 3. The PRL can be used:

children.text: To indicate which requirements are to be implemented in a project-specific implementation.

attributesChanged.text: A user or specification writer to indicate which requirements are to be implemented in a project-specific implementation.

children.text: As a checklist to reduce the risk of failure to conform to this document through oversight.
