children.heading: Priority Request Entry Number
children.text: This object represents the row number in the priority request table. It is used by a management application for identification purposes.
children.name: priorityRequestEntryNumber

children.heading: Priority Request ID
children.text: This object is the 'PRG requested' priority request identifier. It is assigned by the priority request generator so that further information related to a priority request can be identified. It shall be unique for this intersection from a vehicle ID of vehicle type.
children.name: priorityRequestID

attributesChanged.text: This object is the 'PRG requested' priority request identifier. It is assigned by the priority request generator so that further information related to a priority request can be identified. It shall be unique for this intersection from a vehicle ID of vehicle type.

children.heading: Priority Request Vehicle ID
children.text: This object is the 'PRG requested' globally unique identifier of the entity requesting priority. For fleet vehicles, this is assumed to be the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN). For management centers, the value is not defined but shall still be unique to differentiate the source of the priority request.
children.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to align with SAE J2945/B and to increase user privacy.
children.name: priorityRequestVehicleID

children.heading: Priority Request Vehicle Class Type
children.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' class type (relative precedence of a request). The order of precedence is by class type with

1 highest;

…

10 lowest

A request with a higher class type shall override a lower class type.
children.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to increase user privacy.
children.name: priorityRequestVehicleClassType

attributesChanged.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' class type (relative priority of a request). The order of precedence is by class type with
1 highest;
…
10 lowest
A request with a higher class type shall override a lower class type.

children.heading: Priority Request Vehicle Class Level
children.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' class level (relative precedence of a request within each class of request). The order of precedence is by class type and then class level.

1 highest;

…

10 lowest


A request with a higher class level does NOT override a lower class level.
children.name: priorityRequestVehicleClassLevel

attributesChanged.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' class level (relative priority of a request within each class of request). The order of precedence is by class type and then class level.
1 highest;
…
10 lowest

A request with a higher class level does NOT override a lower class level.

children.heading: Priority Request Service Strategy Number
children.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' strategy (1..255) or 0 indicating the PRS has reset the value to none.

The PRS only checks for non-zero value in a request. The CO determines whether a specific value represents a valid strategy. A PRG shall never set this to a value of zero (0). If it does, a PRS shall return a badValue error.
children.name: priorityRequestServiceStrategyNumber

discussion.comment:
It is confusing to say that "a PRG shall never set this" given that this is defined as a read-only object. Are these objects supposed to be MAX-ACCESS read-write (e.g., when the PRG is at central and the PRS is in the field) or are they always read-only? If always read-only and this value is provided by the PRG, we should use different terminology indicating that the value is requested by the PRG through another mechanism.


Also, if we do make read-write, we should update badValue to reference an appropriate SNMPv3 response.

history.updatedComment: It is confusing to say that "a PRG shall never set this" given that this is defined as a read-only object. Are these objects supposed to be MAX-ACCESS read-write (e.g., when the PRG is at central and the PRS is in the field) or are they always read-only? If always read-only and this value is provided by the PRG, we should use different terminology indicating that the value is requested by the PRG through another mechanism.

attributesChanged.info: NTCIP 1211 v03 changed the error response from badValue to xxx to reflect the change to SNMPv3.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Service Desired
children.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' desired time in seconds to arrive at the intersection's stopping point relative to the receipt of the message. A near side stopping point is assumed to be sufficiently close to the intersection's stop bar that regular queues frequently back up across the stopping point. In this case, advance queue clearance prior to the arrival of fleet vehicle is normally required. For all practical purposes, arrival at the stopping point is the same as arrival at the stop bar.
This is a relative time.

Note that it is the responsibility of the PRG to take into account any communications delays between the PRG and the PRS.
children.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to more accurately capture times based on synchronized clocks using the new time format.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesired

attributesChanged.info: This object was deleted in v03 to accommodate a single service time based on the content of the request.
This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate a single service time based on the content of the request.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Estimated Departure
children.text:
This object is the 'PRG requested' estimated time in seconds of departure from the intersection's stopping point relative to the receipt of the message.
This is a relative time.

Note that it is the responsibility of the PRG to take into account any communications delays between the PRG and the PRS.
children.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to more accurately capture times based on synchronized clocks using the new time format.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfEstimatedDeparture

attributesChanged.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to more accurately capture times based on synchronized clocks.

children.heading: Priority Request Status
children.text:
This object provides status information about requests in the PRG. It is also passed to the CO as control information.

Upon receipt of a activeProcessing or a activeAdjustNotNeeded from the CO, the PRS may change the status to:

- activeCancel - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

- activeOverride - upon receipt of a prgPriorityRequest with higher class

Upon receipt of a closedTimerError, closedStrategyError, closedCanceled, closedCompleted, closedTimeToLiveError or closedFlash from the CO, the PRS may change the status to idleNotValid upon receipt of a prgPriorityClear or a timeout of TimeToLive.

Upon receipt of a activeNotOverridden from the CO, the PRS may change the status to activeCancel upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel.

Upon receipt of a readyOverridden from the CO, the PRS may change

the status to:

- readyQueued – upon completion of overriding request

- closedCanceled - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

- closedTimeToLiveError – a timeout of TimeToLive

When the status is idleNotValid, the PRS may change the status to:

- readyQueued – upon receipt of a valid prgPriorityRequest

- reserviceError - upon receipt of a prgPriorityRequest that came too soon after a previous request

When the status is readyQueued, the PRS may change the status to:

- closedCanceled - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

- closedTimeToLiveError – a timeout of TimeToLive
children.format:
idleNotValid        - PRG determined that row does not contain valid 
                      data
readyQueued         - PRG has validated the request but is waiting for
                      the CO to activate
readyOverridden     - CO has overridden the request
activeProcessing    -  CO is processing the requested strategy
activeCancel        - PRS has asked that request be canceled
activeOverride      - PRS has asked that request be overridden
activeNotOverridden -  CO did not process the requested override
closedCanceled      - CO has canceled the request
reserviceError      - PRS determined that the request came too soon 
                      after a previous request
closedTimeToLiveError - PRG determined that TSD exceeds the time to 
                      live
closedTimerError    - CO indicated that the requested times could not
                      be met
closedStrategyError - CO indicated that the requested strategy was not
                      valid
closedCompleted     - CO has completed the requested strategy
activeAdjustNotNeeded - CO indicated that the request can be met by 
                      the current timing and no adjustment is necessary
closedFlash         - CO indicated that the controller is in flash
children.info: A change of status is predicated on the 'busy' signal being set.
children.name: priorityRequestStatusInPRS
children.syntax:
INTEGER { idleNotValid (1),
 readyQueued (2),
 readyOverridden (3),
 activeProcessing (4),
 activeCancel (5),
 activeOverride (6),
 activeNotOverridden (7),
 closedCanceled (8),
 ReserviceError (9),
 closedTimeToLiveError (10),
 closedTimerError (11),
 closedStrategyError (12),
 closedCompleted (13),
 activeAdjustNotNeeded (14),
 closedFlash (15) }

discussion.comment: The definition talks about receiving a value, but this is read-only. It either needs to be made read-write or the definition needs to be revised to better explain what is meant.

readyQueued PRG has validated the request but is waiting for the CO to activate
readyOverridden CO has overridden the request
activeProcessing CO is processing the requested strategy
activeCancel PRS has asked that request be canceled
activeOverride PRS has asked that request be overridden
activeNotOverridden CO did not process the requested override
closedCanceled CO has canceled the request
reserviceError PRS determined that the request came too soon after a previous request
closedTimeToLiveError PRG determined that TSD exceeds the time to live
closedTimerError CO indicated that the requested times could not be met
closedStrategyError CO indicated that the requested strategy was not valid
closedCompleted CO has completed the requested strategy
activeAdjustNotNeeded CO indicated that the request can be met by the current timing and no adjustment is necessary
closedFlash CO indicated that the controller is in flash

Upon receipt of a activeProcessing or a activeAdjustNotNeeded from the CO, the PRS may change the status to:
activeCancel - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel
activeOverride - upon receipt of a prgPriorityRequest with higher class

Upon receipt of a closedTimerError, closedStrategyError, closedCanceled, closedCompleted, closedTimeToLiveError or closedFlash from the CO, the PRS may change the status to:
idleNotValid – upon receipt of a prgPriorityClear or a timeout of TimeToLive

Upon receipt of a activeNotOverridden from the CO, the PRS may
change the status to:
activeCancel - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

Upon receipt of a readyOverridden from the CO, the PRS may change
the status to:
readyQueued – upon completion of overriding request
closedCanceled - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel
closedTimeToLiveError – a timeout of TimeToLive

When the status is idleNotValid, the PRS may change the status to:
readyQueued – upon receipt of a valid prgPriorityRequest
reserviceError - upon receipt of a prgPriorityRequest that came too soon after a previous request

When the status is readyQueued, the PRS may change the status to:
closedCanceled - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel
closedTimeToLiveError – a timeout of TimeToLive

Note: A change of status is predicated on the 'busy' signal being set.

This object provides status information about requests in the PRG. It is also passed to the CO as control information.



Upon receipt of a activeProcessing or a activeAdjustNotNeeded from the CO, the PRS may change the status to:

activeCancel - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

activeOverride - upon receipt of a prgPriorityRequest with higher class


Upon receipt of a closedTimerError, closedStrategyError, closedCanceled, closedCompleted, closedTimeToLiveError or closedFlash from the CO, the PRS may change the status to:

idleNotValid – upon receipt of a prgPriorityClear or a timeout of TimeToLive


Upon receipt of a activeNotOverridden from the CO, the PRS may

change the status to:

activeCancel - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel


Upon receipt of a readyOverridden from the CO, the PRS may change

the status to:

readyQueued – upon completion of overriding request

closedCanceled - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

closedTimeToLiveError – a timeout of TimeToLive


When the status is idleNotValid, the PRS may change the status to:

readyQueued – upon receipt of a valid prgPriorityRequest

reserviceError - upon receipt of a prgPriorityRequest that came too soon after a previous request


When the status is readyQueued, the PRS may change the status to:

closedCanceled - upon receipt of a prgPriorityCancel

closedTimeToLiveError – a timeout of TimeToLive


Note: A change of status is predicated on the 'busy' signal being set.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Message
children.text:
This object represents the initial time of receipt of the priority request. The value of GLO.globalTime is copied to this object when new priority request is first entered in the priorityRequestTable.
Alternatively, this value may be computed or measured by the device depending on the specific system implementation as directed by the priorityRequestTimeOfRequest object below.
children.info: This object used an invalid range that would cause problems with times beyond 2038. This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfMessage

attributesChanged.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps.

children.heading: Priority Request Time to Live
children.text: This object represents the initial time of receipt of the priority request priorityRequestTimeOfMessage plus priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue. When GLO.globalTime is equivalent to this value, a priority request that has a priorityRequestStatusInPRS of 'readyX' or 'closedX' shall have the priorityRequestStatusInPRS set to 'idleNotValid'.
children.info: This object used an invalid range that would cause problems with times beyond 2038. This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeToLive

attributesChanged.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Service Desired (CO)
children.text: This object is the 'PRS requested' desired time (GLO.globalTime) to arrive at the intersection's stopping point. It is derived by adding priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesired to priorityRequestTimeOfMessage.
children.info: This object used an invalid range that would cause problems with times beyond 2038. This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps while using a single time under the assumption that clocks are synchronized.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesiredInPRS

attributesChanged.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate a single time as provided in the request.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Estimated Departure (PRS)
children.text: This object is the 'PRS requested' time (GLO.globalTime) of departure from the intersection's stopping point. It is derived by adding priorityRequestTimeOfEstimatedDeparture to priorityRequestTimeOfMessage.
children.info: This object used an invalid range that would cause problems with times beyond 2038. This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfEstimatedDepartureInPRS

attributesChanged.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate synchronized timing.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Request
children.text: This object represents the initial time within the PRG that the priority request was generated (transmitted) by the PRG. This value represents the number of seconds since midnight January 1, 1970. The value is used to compensate for time differences between the clocks of the PRG and PRS and the variability of the communications delays between the PRG and the PRS where they are separate entities. Note that this object assumes that the PRS has prior knowledge of the time reference used by the PRG (e.g. GPS). If this object contains a zero, then the priorityRequestTimeOfMessage represents the time the message is received. However, if this contains a non-zero value, then it is used to compare the time in the PRS to the time the message was generated, adjusted for any time differences, and used to set the value of priorityRequestTimeOfMessage.
children.info: This object used an invalid range that would cause problems with times beyond 2038. This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate the updated version of timestamps.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfRequest

attributesChanged.info: This object was deprecated in v03 to accommodate a new time format.

children.heading: Priority Request Requester Identifier
children.text: This object is the globally unique identifier used by the entity to request priority. This is typically an identifier assigned by the authority that manages the priority service. It can be designed to provide general classification information (e.g., an emergency vehicle) or can provide various levels of details about the requester (e.g. ladder equipped fire truck #27 from Capital City).
children.info: An AutonomousType is an OBJECT IDENTIFIER that identifies an entity, such as a vehicle.
children.name: priorityRequestRequesterID

attributesChanged.heading: Priority Request Vehicle ID
attributesChanged.text: This object is the 'PRG requested' globally unique identifier of the entity requesting priority. For fleet vehicles, this is assumed to be the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN). For management centers, the value is not defined but shall still be unique to differentiate the source of the priority request.

For management centers, the value is not defined but shall still be unique to differentiate the source of the priority request.

It can be designed to provide general classification information (e.g., an emergency vehicle) or can provide various levels of details about the requester (e.g. ladder equipped fire truck from Capital City .

children.heading: Priority Request Requester Name
children.text: A descriptive name used by the entity requesting priority. This information may be provided by the entity requesting priority according to local policies. If the request does not contain a name, this object shall be a zero-length string.
children.name: priorityRequestRequesterName

children.heading: Priority Request Termination Time
children.text: This object represents the time at which the priorityRequestStatusInPRS value for this priority request shall transition from any 'readyX' or 'closedX' state to the 'idleNotValid' state. The value stored in this object shall reflect the local time of day of the priorityRequestTimeOfMessageV3 plus priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue.
children.name: priorityRequestTerminationTime

attributesChanged.comment: The rollover occurs at a value of 86400000 rather than the max value, which is designed for leap seconds and error conditions. Because priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue has a range of 65535 seconds, the time indicated by this object will always occur at the first instance of ISO26048-1-Clock.fdClockUtcTime being equal with the priorityRequestTerminationTime following the receipt of the request.

attributesChanged.text: This object represents the time at which the priorityRequestStatusInPRS value for this priority request shall transition from any 'readyX' or 'closedX' state to the 'idleNotValid' state. The value stored in this object shall be equal to the priorityRequestTimeOfMessageV3 plus priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue (rolling over at midnight).

This object represents the time at which the priorityRequestStatusInPRS value for this priority request shall transition from any 'readyX' or 'closedX' state to the 'idleNotValid' state. The value stored in this object shall reflect the local time of day of the priorityRequestTimeOfMessageV3 plus priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue (rolling over at midnight).

attributesChanged.info: The rollover occurs at a value of 86400000 rather than the max value, which is designed for leap seconds and error conditions. Because priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue has a range of 65535 seconds, the time indicated by this object will always occur at the first instance of ISO26048-1-Clock.fdClockUtcTime being equal with the priorityRequestTerminationTime following the receipt of the request.

children.heading: Priority Request Arrival Time
children.text: This object indicates the time at which the requester wishes to arrive at the intersection's stopping point.
children.format: Values referencing a daily time that will occur within the next 65535 seconds (i.e., the time-to-live range) after the current time shall reference a future daily times (e.g., possibly on the next day). Values referencing a daily time that has occurred within the last 3600 seconds shall reference a time in the past. Times that are more than an hour in the past or 65535 seconds into the future are invalid and shall not be reported.
children.info: A service request can remain active beyond its requested time, but generally only for one signal cycle. It is assumed that a request never needs to be active an hour after the requested time of service.
children.name: priorityRequestArrivalTime

discussion.comment:
We had discussed making this a reference to the top of the hour, however the time-to-live parameter is currently 65535 seconds (18 hours) making a measurement on the hour ambiguous. 

Even this design has some odd logic and given that saving a few octets on this interface is not criticial, it may be better to just use ITSTimeStamp (i.e., 8-octets to the ms level)

attributesChanged.comment: The rollover occurs at a value of 86400000 rather than the max value, which is designed for leap seconds and error conditions.

attributesChanged.text: This object is the 'PRS requested' desired time (ISO26048-1-Clock.fdClockUtcTime) to arrive at the intersection's stopping point. It is derived by adding priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesired to priorityRequestTimeOfMessageV3 (rolling over at midnight).

attributesChanged.heading: Priority Request Time of Service Desired (CO)

attributesChanged.text: This object is the 'PRS requested' desired time to arrive at the intersection's stopping point as measured from the top of the hour. It is derived by adding priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesired to priorityRequestTimeOfMessageV3 (rolling over at midnight).
This object indicates the desired time of service, typically the expected arrival time at the intersection's stopping point as measured from the top of the hour.

attributesChanged.heading: Priority Request Time of Service Desired — Version 3

attributesChanged.format:
Values 36001 - 36100 are reserved;

Values 36101 - 36200 can be used for manufacturer-specific codes;

Values greater than 36200 are reserved.

attributesChanged.text: This object indicates the desired time of service, typically the expected arrival time at the intersection's stopping point as measured from the top of the hour in tenths of seconds.

attributesChanged.format:
Values 36001 - 36100 are reserved;

Values 36101 - 36200 can be used for manufacturer-specific codes;

Values 36200 - 65534 are reserved; 

65535 - indicates a time more than

attributesChanged.info: The rollover occurs at a value of 86400000 rather than the max value, which is designed for leap seconds and error conditions.

attributesChanged.heading: Priority Request Time of Service Requested
attributesChanged.text: This object indicates the desired time of service, typically the expected arrival time at the intersection's stopping point.

children.heading: Priority Request Departure Time
children.text: This object indicates the time at which the requester estimates it will be ready to depart from the intersection's stopping point.
children.format: Values referencing a daily time that will occur within the next 65535 seconds (i.e., the time-to-live range) after the current time shall reference a future daily times (e.g., possibly on the next day). Values referencing a daily time that has occurred within the last 3600 seconds shall reference a time in the past. Times that are more than an hour in the past or 65535 seconds into the future are invalid and shall not be reported.
children.info: The departure time can be different than the arrival time, for example a bus might request a later departure time to accommodate a near-side bus stop.
children.name: priorityRequestDepartureTime

attributesChanged.heading: Priority Request Arrival Time
attributesChanged.text: This object indicates the time at which the requester wishes to arrive at the intersection's stopping point.

attributesChanged.info: A service request can remain active beyond its requested time, but generally only for one signal cycle. It is assumed that a request never needs to be active an hour after the requested time of service.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Service Estimated
children.text: This object is the 'PRS requested' time (ISO26048-1-Clock.fdClockUtcTime) of departure from the intersection's stopping point. It is derived by adding priorityRequestTimeOfEstimatedDeparture to priorityRequestTimeOfMessageV3 (rolling over at midnight).
children.format: Values referencing a daily time that will occur within the next 65535 seconds (i.e., the time-to-live range) after the current time shall reference a future daily times (e.g., possibly on the next day). Values referencing a daily time that has occurred within the last 18000 seconds shall reference a time in the past. Times that are more than an hour in the past or 65535 seconds into the future are invalid and shall not be reported.
children.info: An entry can remain in the table after it is served to allow discovery of when it was served, but the entry should be deleted within 5 hours to prevent confusing values.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfServiceEstimated

discussion.comment:
We had discussed making this a reference to the top of the hour, however the time-to-live parameter is currently 65535 seconds (18 hours) making a measurement on the hour ambiguous. 

Even this design has some odd logic and given that saving a few octets on this interface is not criticial, it may be better to just use ITSTimeStamp (i.e., 8-octets to the ms level). In particular there are issues with old data in the table (i.e., queries to determine when a request was serviced)

attributesChanged.heading: Priority Request Time of Estimated Departure (PRS)

attributesChanged.info: Values referencing a daily time that will occur within the next 65535 seconds (i.e., the time-to-live range) after the current time shall reference a future daily times (e.g., possibly on the next day). Values referencing a daily time that has occurred within the last 3600 seconds shall reference a time in the past. Times that are more than an hour in the past or 65535 seconds into the future are invalid and shall not be reported.

history.updatedComment:
We had discussed making this a reference to the top of the hour, however the time-to-live parameter is currently 65535 seconds (18 hours) making a measurement on the hour ambiguous. 

Even this design has some odd logic and given that saving a few octets on this interface is not criticial, it may be better to just use ITSTimeStamp (i.e., 8-octets to the ms level)

attributesChanged.info: Values referencing a daily time that will occur within the next 65535 seconds (i.e., the time-to-live range) after the current time shall reference a future daily times (e.g., possibly on the next day). Values referencing a daily time that has occurred within the last 18000 seconds shall reference a time in the past. Times that are more than five hours in the past or 65535 seconds into the future are invalid and shall not be reported.

children.heading: Priority Request Time of Request — Version 3
children.text: This object represents the initial time that the priority request was received by the PRS.
children.info: Time in UTC prevents ambiguities arising during daylight saving time transitions.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeOfRequestV3

discussion.comment: This has been greatly simplified on the assumption that we will require clock synchronization.

children.heading: Priority Request Server Busy
children.text:
This object is used to indicate to a CO that the PRS is initializing or otherwise processing and, when TRUE, the information included with it in a prsServiceRequest response is not valid. It is used to synchronize exchanges between a PRS and CO.


When the CO is acting as an SNMP command generator and the PRS is acting as an SNMP command responder, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO performs a SetRequest prsServiceRequest.


When the PRS is acting as an SNMP command generator and the CO is acting as the SNMP command responder, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO responds to a GetRequest prsServiceRequest from the PRS with coBusy set to FALSE.
children.name: prsBusy

discussion.comment: prsServiceRequest is defined in the CO MIB and therefore would not be present in the PRS to be set by the CO.

attributesChanged.text:
This object is used to indicate to a CO that the PRS is initializing or otherwise processing and, when TRUE, the information included with it in a prsServiceRequest response is not valid. It is used to synchronize exchanges between a PRS and CO.

When the CO is acting as manager and the PRS is acting as an agent, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO performs a SetRequest prsServiceRequest.

When the PRS is acting as a manager and the CO is acting as the agent, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO responds to a GetRequest prsServiceRequest from the PRS with coBusy set to FALSE.

This object is used to indicate to a CO that the PRS is initializing or otherwise processing and, when TRUE, the information included with it in a prsServiceRequest response is not valid. It is used to synchronize exchanges between a PRS and CO.


When the CO is acting as an SNMP command requester and the PRS is acting as an SNMP command responder, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO performs a SetRequest prsServiceRequest.


When the PRS is acting as a command requester and the CO is acting as the command responder, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO responds to a GetRequest prsServiceRequest from the PRS with coBusy set to FALSE.

This object is used to indicate to a CO that the PRS is initializing or otherwise processing and, when TRUE, the information included with it in a prsServiceRequest response is not valid. It is used to synchronize exchanges between a PRS and CO.


When the CO is acting as an SNMP command generator and the PRS is acting as an SNMP command responder, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO performs a SetRequest prsServiceRequest.


When the PRS is acting as a command SNMP generator and the CO is acting as the SNMP command responder, prsBusy is set TRUE when the CO responds to a GetRequest prsServiceRequest from the PRS with coBusy set to FALSE.

children.heading: Priority Request Time to Live Value
children.text: This object represents the value (expressed in seconds) that is added to the current time (ISO26048-1-Clock.fdClockUtcTime) and loaded into priorityRequestTerminationTime when a priority request is initially entered in the table.
children.info: The definition of this object was revised in v03 to accommodate the migration from GLO.globalTime to ISO 26048-1-Clock.fdClockUtcTime.
children.name: priorityRequestTimeToLiveValue

attributesChanged.text: This object represents the value (expressed in seconds) that is added to the current value of GLO.globalTime and loaded into priorityRequestTimeToLive when a priority request is initially entered in the table.

children.heading: Priority Request Reservice Timer
children.text:
This object represents a timer that is reset to zero at the completion of any strategy (priorityRequestStatusInPRS is initially set equal to 'closedCompleted'). It is incremented every second up to its maximum value of 65535 where it latches.

This timer is compared to priorityRequestReserviceClass<X> Times to determine whether a priority request that comes right after a previous will be honored.
children.name: priorityRequestReserviceTimer

children.text: Objects used to describe the messages related to the priority request server (PRS).
children.name: priorityRequestMessages

children.heading: Priority Request Message
children.text:
An OER encoded string of reference parameters to initiate a new 
priority request.

SEQUENCE {
  priorityRequestID                       INTEGER (1..255),
  priorityRequestVehicleID                OCTET STRING (SIZE 17),
  priorityRequestVehicleClassType         INTEGER (1..10),
  priorityRequestVehicleClassLevel        INTEGER (1..10),
  priorityRequestServiceStrategyNumber    INTEGER (1..255),
  priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesired     INTEGER (1..65535),
  priorityRequestTimeOfEstimatedDeparture INTEGER (1..65535) }
children.info: This object was no longer referenced within the RTM and replaced with prgPriorityRequestAbsolute in v02 but its status was inadvertently not changed to deprecated. In v03, that status was updated to deprecated.
children.name: prgPriorityRequest

An OER encoded string of the following structure to clear a 
priority request.

SEQUENCE {
  priorityRequestID                    INTEGER (1..255),
  priorityRequestRequesterID           AutonomousType,
  priorityRequestRequesterName         SnmpAdminString (SIZE(0..63)),
  priorityRequestVehicleClassType      INTEGER (1..10),
  priorityRequestVehicleClassLevel     INTEGER (1..10),
  priorityRequestServiceStrategyNumber INTEGER (1..255) }
children.name: prgPriorityClear

children.name: scpCo

attributesChanged.text: This MIB defines the data elements that would reside in a Priority Request Server (PRS).

children.text: NTCIP 1211 v03 – Upgraded to SMIv2 format and incorporated objects from ISO 26048-1 into the design.

NTCIP 1211 v02 - Added systems engineering content, including Section 2(Concept of Operations), Section 3 (Requirements), Section 4 (Dialogs), and Annex A (Requirements Traceability Table) along with other refinements based on lessons learned.
NTCIP 1211 v01 - Initial version of NTCIP 1211.
Objects used to describe the output from the prioritization process and the parameters that Coordinator acts upon.
children.name: priorityStrategyServer

attributesChanged.text: Objects used to describe the data elements for the priority request server (PRS).

children.heading: Maximum Service Requests to Consider
children.text: This object represents the number of rows in the priorityStrategyRequestedTable that the CO shall consider when it tries to determine which strategies to execute. The number of rows in the table is fixed at 10 but an implementation is only required to act upon the first row.
children.name: maxStrategyRequestsToConsider

children.heading: Priority Strategy Requested Table
children.text: A static table containing the parameters associated with executing a priority strategy. The number of rows in this table is equal to 10.
children.name: priorityStrategyRequestedTable

children.text: This object defines the parameters that are associated with a service request.

priorityStrategyRequestedEntry

children.heading: Priority Strategy Request Number
children.text: This object represents the index used to reference rows in the priorityStrategyRequestedTable.
children.name: priorityStrategyRequestNumber

children.heading: Priority Strategy Requested
children.text: This object represents a strategy being requested by the PRS. A value of zero (0) shall indicate that none is request.
children.name: priorityStrategyRequested

children.heading: Priority Strategy Requested Time of Service Desired
children.text: This object represents the estimated time of service desired expressed as global time. This value is received from the PRS via the prsServiceRequest message's priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesiredInPRS.
children.name: priorityStrategyRequestedTimeOfServiceDesired

children.heading: Priority Strategy Requested Time of Estimated Departure
children.text: This object represents the estimated time of departure expressed as global time. This value is received from the PRS via the prsServiceRequest message's priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesiredInPRS.
children.name: priorityStrategyRequestedTimeOfEstimatedDeparture

children.heading: Priority Strategy Request Status (CO)
children.text:
This object provides an image of priorityRequestStatusInPRS that was sent by the PRS or a response to readyQueued, activeCancel, or activeOverride.
idleNotValid PRS determined that the request does not contain valid data
readyQueued PRS has validated the request but is waiting for the CO to activate
readyOverridden CO has overridden the request
activeProcessing CO is processing the requested strategy
activeCancel PRS has asked that request be canceled
activeOverride PRS has asked that request be overridden
activeNotOverridden CO did not process the requested override
closedCanceled CO has canceled the request
reserviceError PRs determined that the request came too soon after a previous request
closedTimeToLiveError PRS determined that TSD exceeds the time to live
closedTimerError CO determined that the requested times could not be met
closedStrategyError CO determined that the requested strategy was not valid.
ClosedCompleted CO has completed the requested strategy request
ActiveAdjustNotNeeded CO determined that the request could be met with current timing and adjustment was not needed
ClosedFlash CO determined that the controller was operating in flash.

Upon receipt of a readyQueued, the CO may change the status to:
activeProcessing
closedTimerError
closedStrategyError
activeAdjustNotNeeded
closedFlash

Upon receipt of a activeCancel, the CO may change the status to:
closedCanceled
closedCompleted

Upon receipt of a activeOverride, the CO may change the status to:
activeNotOverridden
readyOverridden
closedCompleted

The CO does NOT take any action when one of the following status is received from the PRS:
idleNotValid
readyOverridden
activeProcessing
activeNotOverridden
closedCanceled
reserviceError
closedTimeToLiveError
closedTimerError
closedStrategyError
closedCompleted
activeAdjustNotNeeded
closedFlash

Note: A change of status is predicated on the
children.name: priorityStrategyRequestStatusInCO
children.syntax:
INTEGER { idleNotValid (1),
 readyQueued (2),
 readyOverridden (3),
 activeProcessing (4),
 activeCancel (5),
 activeOverride (6),
 activeNotOverridden (7),
 closedCanceled (8),
 reserviceError (9),
 closedTimeToLiveError (10),
 closedTimerError (11),
 closedStrategyError (12),
 closedCompleted (13),
 activeAdjustNotNeeded (14),
 closedFlash (15) }

children.heading: Priority Strategy Time of Service Estimated
children.text: This object represents the estimated time that the request will be serviced.
children.name: priorityStrategyTimeOfServiceEstimated

children.heading: Coordinator Busy
children.text:
This object is used to indicate to a PRS that the CO is initializing or otherwise processing and when TRUE, the information included with it in a prsServiceRequest response is not valid. It is used to synchronize exchanges between a PRS and CO.

When the PRS is acting as manager and the CO is acting as an agent, coBusy is set TRUE when the PRS performs a SetRequest prsServiceRequest.

When the CO is acting as a manager and the PRS is acting as the agent, coBusy is set TRUE when the PRS responds to a GetRequest prsServiceRequest from the CO with prsBusy set to FALSE.
children.name: coBusy

children.text:
The following set of objects defines a table of priority strategy

parameters and a list of per unit parameters. In the table, each row

in the table represents data associated with a particular strategy.
children.name: comment

children.heading: Priority Strategies Max
children.text: The maximum number of priority strategies supported by this entity.
children.name: priorityStrategiesMax

children.heading: Priority Strategies Table
children.text: A static table containing the parameters associated with each priority strategy. The number of rows in this table is equal to the priorityStrategiesMax object.
children.name: priorityStrategyTable

children.text: Parameters associated with a specific priority strategy.
children.name: priorityStrategyEntry
priorityStrategyEntry
children.syntax:
{
priorityStrategyNumber INTEGER,
priorityStrategyServicePhases OCTET STRING,
priorityStrategyPhaseOmits OCTET STRING,
priorityStrategyPedOmits OCTET STRING,
priorityStrategyDescription OCTET STRING}

children.heading: Priority Strategy Number
children.text: This object serves as the index in the priorityStrategyTable.
children.name: priorityStrategyNumber

children.heading: Priority Strategy Service Phases
children.text:
This object defines the phase or phases that represent the movement on which priority service is desired. Each octet (binary value) within the octet string contains an SCP.phaseNumber.

There can only be one phase per ring. All defined Service Phases shall be able to time concurrently. It is assumed that any possible concurrent phase are allowed to be serviced in order with no backing up unless otherwise permitted.
children.name: priorityStrategyServicePhases

children.heading: Priority Strategy Phase Omits
children.text: This object represents the phase(s) that are to be omitted during the priority service. Each octet (binary value) within the octet string contains an SCP.phaseNumber. The CO shall ignore any omit applied to the coordinated phase(s). These phase omits are logically 'OR'ed with any other phase omits that may be active.
children.name: priorityStrategyPhaseOmits

children.heading: Priority Strategy Ped Omits
children.text: This object represents the pedestrian movement(s) that are to be omitted during the priority service. Each octet (binary value) within the octet string contains an SCP.phaseNumber. These ped omits are logically 'OR'ed with any other ped omits that may be active. These ped omits do not apply to non-actuated phases.
children.name: priorityStrategyPedOmits

children.heading: Priority Strategy Description
children.text: This object represents a text description of the strategy. It is intended to convey to priority service requesters what signals or movements are given priority. It should be defined in language that is domain neutral.
children.name: priorityStrategyDescription

children.heading: Priority Strategy Plan Block
children.text:
An OER encoded string of other columns of this entry of this table, 
according following structure. 

SEQUENCE {
  priorityStrategyServicePhases.x  OCTET STRING,
  priorityStrategyPhaseOmits.x     OCTET STRING,
  priorityStrategyPedOmits.x       OCTET STRING,
  priorityStrategyDescription.x    OCTET STRING (SIZE 0..40)}
children.name: coStrategyPlanBlock

children.text:
The following set of objects represent per unit parameters that

apply to all strategies. It includes a set of database variables

that relate to an extension of the splitTable as defined in NTCIP

1202:2005.
children.name: comment

children.heading: Priority Strategy Extension to Split Table
children.text:
A table containing priority strategy parameters that are associated with each split and each phase of that split.


This is an extension to the splitTable as defined in the NTCIP 1202:2005.
children.name: priorityStrategyExtensionToSplitTable

attributesChanged.text:
A table containing priority strategy parameters that are associated with each split and each phase of that split.

This is an extension to the splitTable as defined in the NTCIP 1202:2005.

children.text: A table containing priority strategy parameters that are associated with each split and each phase of that split.
children.name: priorityStrategyExtensionToSplitEntry

children.heading: Priority Strategy Maximum Reduction Time
children.text:
This object represents the maximum number of seconds that the split of a phase can be reduced by during a priority strategy.

This effective value may be reduced by the CO based on the operating phase minimum service requirements.

Note - The definition of a phases minimum service is dependent on whether it is actuated or non-actuated, whether the ped clear terminates before the yellow or not, whether variable initial is active or not, whether it is a coord phase or not, and whether it is in a single or multi-ring configuration.
children.name: priorityStrategyMaximumReductionTime

children.heading: Priority Strategy Maximum Extension Time
children.text:
This object represents the maximum number of seconds that the split of a phase can be extended during a priority strategy.

The effective value may be modified by the CO based on time gained from one cycle of reductions to the respective non-priority phases.
children.name: priorityStrategyMaximumExtensionTime

children.heading: Priority Strategy Split Extension Block Table
children.text:
A table containing a block of priority strategy parameters for each phase of an indicated split.

This is an extension to the splitTable as defined in the NTCIP 1202:2005.
children.name: scpCoStrategySplitBlockTable

children.text: A table containing priority strategy parameters that are associated with each split and each phase of that split.
children.name: scpCoStrategySplitBlockEntry

children.heading: Priority Strategy Split Block
children.text:
An OER encoded string of other columns of this entry of this table, 
according following structure, where each x equals the splitNumber (i.e., the index of this object) and y is defined as:
    
    for (y = 1; y <= maxPhases; y++)

SEQUENCE OF SEQUENCE {
priorityStrategyMaximumReductionTime.x.y INTEGER (0..255),
priorityStrategyMaximumExtensionTime.x.y INTEGER (0..255) }

Data for all phases between 1 and maxPhases, inclusive, shall be present.
children.name: scpCoStrategySplitBlock

children.name: prsServiceRequestV3

discussion.comment:
Need to determine how we want to present time throughout the document. We have already suggested that we need decisecond resolution, which requires a change. Possible options include:

  • Always using the eight-octet ITSTimeStamp structure (ms since 1970)
  • Storing the time in tables as 8-octet but only exchanging the lower 4 octets in SEQUENCE constructs (i.e., there is a clear definition of when within the controller - this would also require logic to ensire that times beyond the 49-day rollover cycle were always idleNotValid)
  • Using the ITSDailyTimeMs structure (ms since midnight) but then we need to have more complex logic related to rollovers
  • A new decisecond structure, but this creates a new structure without providing any real bandwisth savings and has all of the probles related with other formats

children.text: This object is an identifier used to group all objects for support of SCP Block Upload and Download activities.
children.name: scpBlock

children.heading: SCP Block Get Control
children.text:
An OER encoded string of reference parameters for SCP Block Uploads. The parameter values in this string are:
scpBlockDataType INTEGER (0..255)
scpBlockDataID INTEGER (0..255)
scpBlockIndex1 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockQuantity1 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockIndex2 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockQuantity2 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockIndex3 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockQuantity3 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockIndex4 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockQuantity4 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockIndex5 INTEGER (0..255) if needed
scpBlockQuantity5 INTEGER (0..255) if needed

A GET of scpBlockData shall utilize values currently in this object to define the data to be returned.

A SET of this object shall be evaluated for validity and Error Status of badValue(3) be returned for the following conditions:
1) scpBlockDataType is not supported
2) scpBlockDataID is not supported
3) scpBlockIndex1 is zero or not supported
4) scpBlockQuantity1 is zero or scpBlockIndex1 + scpBlockQuantity1 - 1 is not supported
5) scpBlockIndex2 is zero or not supported
6) scpBlockQuantity2 is zero or scpBlockIndex2 + scpBlockQuantity2) - 1 is not supported
7) scpBlockIndex3 is zero or not supported
8) scpBlockQuantity3 is zero or scpBlockIndex3 + scpBlockQuantity3) - 1 is not supported
9) scpBlockIndex4 is zero or not supported
10) scpBlockQuantity4 is zero or scpBlockIndex4 + scpBlockQuantity4) - 1 is not supported
11) scpBlockIndex5 is zero or not supported
12) scpBlockQuantity5 is zero or scpBlockIndex5 + scpBlockQuantity5) - 1 is not supported
13) if the SET length is zero or incorrect for scpBlockDataType & scpBlockDataID
14) if the GetResponse length for a GET on scpBlockData using maximum data field sizes would exceed a local limitation

When this validity check fails, scpBlockErrorStatus shall be set equal to the Bullet Value above that generated the error.
children.info: This object was deprecated and withdrawn in v03 due to ambiguities in the intended encoding and lack of an actual need for the structure within the scope of this document.
children.name: scpBlockGetControl
children.x_text: No technical need; its only defined use in the document was to set it to 0x0000.

discussion.comment: Being deprecated due to a lack of need and ambiguity in the structure definition (i.e., the structure is not proper ASN.1, it should be defined as a SEQUENCE with OPTIONAL fields).

children.heading: SCP Block Data
children.text:
An OER encoded string used for uploading and downloading SCP parameters. See SECTION 5 for encoding and decoding the block.

A SET on this object shall require the use of 'dbCreateTransaction' defined in NTCIP 1201 v03 Section 2.3.1.

A SET of this object shall be evaluated for validity and Error Status of badValue(3) be returned for the following conditions:
1) scpBlockDataType is not supported
2) scpBlockDataID is not supported
3) scpBlockIndex1 is zero or not supported
4) scpBlockQuantity1 is zero or scpBlockIndex1 + scpBlockQuantity1 - 1 is not supported
5) scpBlockIndex2 is zero or not supported
6) scpBlockQuantity2 is zero or scpBlockIndex2 + scpBlockQuantity2) - 1 is not supported
7) scpBlockIndex3 is zero or not supported
8) scpBlockQuantity3 is zero or scpBlockIndex3 + scpBlockQuantity3) - 1 is not supported
9) scpBlockIndex4 is zero or not supported
10) scpBlockQuantity4 is zero or scpBlockIndex4 + scpBlockQuantity4) - 1 is not supported
11) scpBlockIndex5 is zero or not supported
12) scpBlockQuantity5 is zero or scpBlockIndex5 + scpBlockQuantity5) - 1 is not supported
13) if the SET length is zero or incorrect for scpBlockDataType & scpBlockDataID
14) if the SET (SEQUENCE OF) value is incorrect.

When this validity check fails, scpBlockErrorStatus shall be set equal to the Bullet Value above that generated the error.

A SET that includes an unsupported value for a supported data element shall return an Error Status of badValue(3) and scpBlockErrorStatus shall be set equal to: (data Sequence # * 100) + data Element #

A SET that includes a non-zero or non-null value in the position of an unsupported data element shall return an Error Status of badValue(3) and scpBlockErrorStatus shall be set equal to: (data Sequence # * 100) + data Element #

A GET on this object shall utilize values currently in scpBlockGetControl to define the data to be returned. When scpBlockGetControl has invalid data, an Error Status of badValue(3) shall be returned.

A GET shall return a zero or null value in the position of an unsupported object.

A SET that includes a non-zero or non-null value in the position of an unsupported data element shall return an Error Status of badValue(3) and scpBlockErrorStatus shall be set equal to: (data Sequence # * 100) + data Element #

A GET on this object shall utilize values currently in scpBlockGetControl to define the data to be returned. When scpBlockGetControl has invalid data, an Error Status of badValue(3) shall be returned.

A GET shall return a zero or null value in the position of an unsupported object.

children.heading: SCP Block Error Status
children.text:
This object defines the data element within scpBlockGetControl or scpBlockData that caused a badValue(3) ErrorStatus.

This object should equal zero after any successful SET to scpBlockGetControl or scpBlockData.
children.name: scpBlockErrorStatus

children.heading: Coordination Processor Block Object Definitions
children.text: All SCP Block Objects shall begin with two octets that define the Data Type and Data ID.

attributesChanged.text: 5.2.4 Coordination Processor Block Object Definitions

children.text: The Data Type octet (scpBlockDataType) provides for the definition of both NTCIP Standard and Device Proprietary data blocks. NTCIP Standard Data Blocks shall utilize an 'scpBlockDataType' of zero. Device Proprietary Data Blocks shall utilize an 'scpBlockDataType' equal to the Private Node Number (PNN) as assigned by NEMA (1.3.6.1.4.1.1206.3.PNN).

Standard Data Block

0XPNN

Device Proprietary Data Block
The Data ID octet (scpBlockDataID) provides for definition of included data parameters. NCTIP Standard Data Blocks shall include an 'scpBlockDataID' as listed in Table 6.

Name

Description

CoStrategyPlanBlock

Defines Priority Phase, Omits, etc.

0x01

CoStrategySplitsBlock

Defines Max Extensions and Reductions

0x02-0x7F

 

Reserved For NTCIP SCP Usage

attributesChanged.text: Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) [Normative]

children.text: The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) links the Functional Requirements with their corresponding Dialogs on the same (gray) line. Each Functional Requirement/Dialog ruses one or more Objects, which are listed underneath the Functional Requirement line. Each referenced item is formally defined in the indicated clause of this or another standard. Using this table, each Functional Requirement can thus be traced in a standardized way.

attributesChanged.text: The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) links the Functional Requirements as presented in Section 3 with the corresponding Dialogs (Section 4.2) on the same (gray) line. Each Functional Requirement/Dialog relates/uses one or more groups of Objects. The Objects (also known as Data Elements) are listed to the side; the formal definition of each object is contained within Section 5. Using this table, each Functional Requirement can thus be traced in a standardized way.

The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) links the Functional Requirements as presented in Section 3 with the corresponding Dialogs (e.g., Section 4.2) on the same (gray) line. Each Functional Requirement/Dialog relates/uses one or more groups of Objects. The Objects (also known as Data Elements) are listed to the side; the formal definition of each object is contained within Section 5. Using this table, each Functional Requirement can thus be traced in a standardized way.

The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) links the Functional Requirements as presented in Section 3 with the corresponding Dialogs (e.g., Section 4.2) on the same (gray) line. Each Functional Requirement/Dialog relates/uses one or more Objects, which are listed underneath. The formal definition of each object is contained within Section 5 or the referenced MIB. Using this table, each Functional Requirement can thus be traced in a standardized way.

The Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) links the Functional Requirements with their corresponding Dialogs on the same (gray) line. Each Functional Requirement/Dialog ruses one or more Objects, which are listed underneath the Functional Requirement line. Using this table, each Functional Requirement can thus be traced in a standardized way.

children.text: Note: Objects defined as tables, entries, or indexes are not traced to any requirement, but the index values are used to identify instances of other tabular objects that are exchanged.

attributesChanged.text: Note: The INDEX objects in any of the tables are not explicitly exchanged but are used as index values for other objects that are exchanged.

children.text: The audience for this table is implementers (vendors and central system developers) and conformance testers. Additionally, other interested parties might use this table to determine how particular functions are to be implemented using the standardized dialogs, interfaces, and object definitions.

To conform to a Functional Requirement, an SCP system shall implement all objects traced from that requirement using any valid SNMP operation conforming to the rules defined by the relevant standards.

attributesChanged.text: To conform to a requirement, an SCP system shall implement all objects traced from that requirement; and unless otherwise indicated, shall implement all dialogs traced from the requirement. To be consistent with a requirement, an SCP system shall be able to fulfill the requirement using only objects that a conforming SCP system is required to support.

children.text: Supplemental Requirements, defined in Section 3.6, do not appear in the RTM as they are self-contained without any additional high-level design details required for interoperability.

attributesChanged.heading: defines Supplemental Requirements, which are refining other functional requirements. These functional requirements in turn are generally traced to design elements (e.g., rather than being directly traced to design elements).

children.text: The functional requirements are defined within Section 3 and the RTM is based upon the requirements within that Section. The section number and the functional requirement name are indicated within these columns.

children.heading: Instructions For Using The RTM [Informative]
children.text: To find the standardized design content for a functional requirement, search for the requirement identification number and functional requirement under the functional requirements columns. Next to the functional requirements column is be a dialog identification number, identifying either a generic dialog (e.g., as defined in ISO 26048-1) or a specified dialog (found in Section 4.2) to be used to fulfill that requirement. To the right of the dialog identification number are the identification number and name of the data objects that are referenced or used by the dialog to fulfill the functional requirement. Object definitions specific to this document can be found in Section 5. If an object is defined in a different standard, the defining module name is listed.

data.heading: Documentation of Revisions [Informative]
data.text: This annex identifies significant changes that have been made to the this document since v02. NTCIP makes reasonable efforts to ensure that the standards are as backward compatible as possible, but the security enhancements made with NTCIP 1211 v03 prevent interoperability with prior versions.

attributesChanged.text: This annex identifies significant changes that have been made to the NTCIP 1211 standard. NTCIP makes reasonable efforts to ensure that the standards are as backward compatible as possible, but the primary purpose of the standard is to provide interoperability by developing standards in a consensus environment. When changes are required to meet these objectives, the problematic objects are refined (if the issue is primarily editorial) or deprecated and, in most cases, replaced with new objects. This annex identifies why each of these changes have been made. New implementations should support the new/replacement objects; they may also support deprecated objects.

data.heading: User Requests [Informative]
data.text: This annex identifies features that were suggested for this standard but either are supported by mechanisms that may not be readily obvious or are not supported by this version of the standard.

children.heading: Features Not Supported by This Version
children.text: The following clauses identify certain features that were considered, but were excluded for this version.

attributesChanged.text: The following clauses identify certain features that were considered for this version, but were excluded from NTCIP 1211 v02.

children.heading: Vehicle Approach
children.text: There is a user need for a traffic signal controller to provide preferential treatment for a fleet vehicle by servicing a specific phase, dependent on what direction the fleet vehicle is approaching the signalized intersection.

This document satisfies this user need, but assumes that the priority strategy information has been provided to and uploaded to the fleet vehicle or the fleet management center, depending on how the SCP system is implemented. With the priority strategy information uploaded, the fleet vehicle or fleet management center may request the appropriate priority strategy via the PRG, based on the direction of travel of the fleet vehicle approaching the signalized intersection.

attributesChanged.text: The implementation of NTCIP 1211 v01 and NTCIP 1211 v02 satisfies this user need, but assumes that the priority strategy information has been provided to and uploaded to the fleet vehicle or the fleet management center, depending on how the SCP system is implemented. With the priority strategy information uploaded, the fleet vehicle or fleet management center may request the appropriate priority strategy via the PRG, based on the direction of travel of the fleet vehicle approaching the signalized intersection.

children.text: For example, the traffic management agency and the fleet management agency or company may agree to configure priority strategy number 5 at a signalized intersection to provide preferential treatment for northbound through vehicles. As the fleet vehicle approaches the intersection from the northbound direction, the PRG would send a priority request asking for priority strategy number 5.

However, if the priority strategy is not uploaded to the fleet vehicle or fleet management center, the PRG is unable to indicate, as the fleet vehicle approaches the signalized intersection, which phase the traffic signal controller should service in the priority request sent to the PRS.

Thus, the user need, for the traffic signal controller to service a specific phase dependent on the direction that the fleet vehicle is approaching the signalized intersection, is only partially satisfied by this document. For situations where the priority strategy information is not uploaded to the fleet vehicle or the fleet management center, this user need is not satisfied.

attributesChanged.text: Thus, the user need, for the traffic signal controller to service a specific phase dependent on the direction that the fleet vehicle is approaching the signalized intersection, is only partially satisfied by NTCIP 1211 v01 and NTCIP 1211 v02. For situations where the priority strategy information is not uploaded to the fleet vehicle or the fleet management center, this user need is not satisfied.

children.text: The SCP WG discussed this and concluded that it would result in a standard that was complex.

attributesChanged.text: The SCP WG discussed this and concluded that it would:

children.text: The SCP WG concludes that the PRG may not know the specific strategy or even the phase that would serve the desired movement, but should know the entering approach, and possibly the exit approach, directions that specify the desired movement of the requesting vehicle at the intersection. The SCP WG is considering proposals for addressing this need in future versions.

attributesChanged.text: The SCP WG revisited this issue in NTCIP 1211 V02 and concludes that the PRG may not know the specific strategy or even the phase that would serve the desired movement, but should know the entering approach, and possibly the exit approach, directions that specify the desired movement of the requesting vehicle at the intersection. The SCP WG is considering proposals for addressing this need in NTCIP 1211 v03 while maintaining backward compatibility.

The SCP WG is considering proposals for addressing this need in NTCIP 1211 v03 while maintaining backward compatibility.

data.heading: SCP Tutorial [Informative]
data.text: Annex F describes how a typical SCP system works.

children.text: In a SCP System, a Fleet Vehicle, Fleet Management, or Traffic Management initiates priority service by instructing the Priority Request Generator to send a Priority Request to a Priority Request Server. The Priority Request Server prioritizes and sorts all requests based upon Class Type and Class Level. It then sends its queue of requests to the Coordinator that resides in a Traffic Signal Controller. Based upon the strategy (or strategies based upon the implementation), the Coordinator attempts to adjust the split timing in the Coordinator to accommodate the service request(s).

children.heading: Coordinator
children.text: Based upon pre-programmed entries, the Coordinator applies phase and pedestrian omits, and increases or decreases non-priority phase splits to extend the priority split time up to some maximum. Figure 26 and Figure 27 illustrate the operation.
Figure 26 Early Return to Coordinated Phase
Figure 27 Late Departure from Coordinated Phase

In Figure 26, a priority request message for priority service on Phase 1 is received at some point prior to the "zero point". Projecting the priorityRequestTimeOfServiceDesired (TSD) into the anticipated timing sequence, the phase 1, 2, 3 and 4 split times are reduced by the priorityStrategyMaximumReductionTime to ensure an early return to Phase 1 green at TSD. [The split times for phases 2, 3, and 4 could have also been reduced to zero (0) by application of priorityStrategyPhaseOmits and/or priorityStrategyPedOmits.]

In Figure 27, the priority request message's priorityRequestTimeOfEstimatedDeparture (TED) would normally occur after Phase 1 would have terminated. In this case, the Phase 1 split time is extended so that Phase 1 remains green so that the fleet vehicle can make its way through the intersection. [The split times for phases 2, 3, and 4 could have also been reduced to zero (0) by application of priorityStrategyPhaseOmits and/or priorityStrategyPedOmits.]

All coordinator calculations that project TSD and TED into a future timing position shall be based upon the current pattern. The calculations are not required to take into consideration a future change in pattern and any transitioning to that new pattern.

children.heading: Typical Sequence Diagram
children.text: The following figure shows a typical sequence of events for an SCP system. The sequence of events depicted assumes that the CO is the manager and the PRS is the agent for communications between the CO and the PRS.

The figure represents a situation where a priority request is initially queued by the PRS and a priority request update is sent prior to the initial priority request being highest in the queue. A service request is then retrieved by the CO and it returns the status of the service request back to the PRS. The status buffer for the priority request is then set up between the PRG and the PRS, and the PRG reads the contents of the status buffer. The CO, again, retrieves a service , and the CO returns a status of complete. The status buffer is set up again to return this status to the PRG, and the status is read. Since the priority request is now complete, the priority request is cleared from the PRS.
Figure 28 Priority Request Sequence Diagram (Typical)
